revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{fanpov|date=September 2012}} {{peacock|date=September 2012}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Angelo Pirotta | birth_date = {{birth date|df=y|1894|12|27}} | birth_place = [[Naxxar]], [[Malta]] | parents = John Mary Pirotta (1867‚Äì1946) and Antonia n√©e Camilleri (1875‚Äì1929) | death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|1956|11|16|1894|12|27}} | death_place = [[Naxxar]], [[Malta]] | occupation = [[Philosophy]] }}
'''Angelo Pirotta''', [[Dominican Order|O.P.]] (December 27, 1894 ‚Äì November 16, 1956) was a major Maltese philosopher. His areas of specialisation in philosophy were chiefly [[epistemology]] and [[metaphysics]].<ref>Mark Montebello, ''Il-Ktieb tal-Filosofija f‚ÄôMalta'' (''A Source Book of Philosophy in Malta''), PIN Publications, Malta, 2001, Vol. II, pp. 50-51.</ref>
==Life==
===The early years=== Pirotta was born at [[Naxxar]], [[Malta]].<ref>All biographical information is reproduced from Mark Montebello‚Äôs ''Angelo Pirotta: A Maltese philosopher of the first water'', Maltese Dominican Province, Malta, 2006, with full permission of the copyright holders.</ref> Even if his family lived hand to mouth, he was the first of thirteen children, three of whom died in infancy.
Pirotta was first privately schooled by Canon Fortunato De Bono. Later, he eventually enrolled on a regular course at the government-owned high school for boys (the Lyceum) at [[Valletta]]. He completed the course at the Lyceum up till the age of sixteen. Thereafter, he joined the [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]] almost immediately, on April 30, 1911.
===Initial formation=== At Rabat, together with his companions, Pirotta began his novitiate, and then, a year later, made his simple (three-year) profession on May 12, 1912. Thereafter, he began his institutional studies; three years of philosophy (1912‚Äì15), and four of theology (1915‚Äì19), of course all according to the [Thomist] tradition. He made his religious profession on May 11, 1915.
After completing his second year of theology (1916/17), Pirotta was chosen to continue his theological studies at [[Pontifical University of St. Thomas Aquinas (Angelicum)|Pontifical International Angelicum College]] in Rome, the future [[Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas|Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas, ''Angelicum'']]. In the meantime, he was ordained a priest by on September 22, 1917, at the [[St. John‚Äôs Co-Cathedral]], [[Valletta]], [[Malta]].
In [[Rome]] Pirotta resided at the [[Angelicum]] College itself. After his two years of theology (1917‚Äì19), on July 1, 1919, he successfully set for his Lectorate exams with a dissertation entitled '''''De Reali Distinctione inter Essentiam et Esse in Creatis''''' (The Real Distinction between Essence and Existence in Created Being). Thereafter, he proceeded with his post-graduate studies in philosophy (1919‚Äì21). Meanwhile, he also prepared his doctorate thesis, entitled '''''De Supposto et Persona''''', which he successfully defended on, July 1, 1921.
===The Italy years===
====At Viterbo==== Pirotta‚Äôs first academic assignment was at [[Viterbo]]. Here he spent five academic years (1921‚Äì26), teaching history of philosophy, natural science (also called ‚Äòphysics‚Äô), and theodicy (''theologia fundamentalis''; now called natural theology). Here he was frequently invited to address the ''Circulus Philosophicus'' (Philosophical Discussion Group), and was also asked to contribute to prestigious Thomistic periodicals, read sermons, and give speeches. At Viterbo, Pirotta also prepared his first major publication, and frankly his most successful composition to date: an exposition of [[Aquinas]]‚Äô commentary on [[Aristotle]]‚Äôs '''''De Anima''''' (On the Soul).
====At Rome==== After [[Viterbo]], Pirotta returned to [[Rome]] to assume a teaching post at the [[Angelicum]] College. Here Pirotta remained for just two years (1926-28), teaching philosophy, theodicy, logic, and ontology.
In terms of literary production, Pirotta‚Äôs Roman years correspond to a very prolific and industrious period. He wrote reviews, scientific articles, and even prepared and published his second major work: another exposition on [[Aquinas]]‚Äô commentaries on [[Aristotle]]‚Äôs '''''De Sensu et Sensato''''' (On Sense and Sensibility) and '''''De Memoria et Reminiscientia''''' (On Memory and Remembrance).
====Interlude in Malta==== In 1928 Pirotta had to retire momentarily to his homeland since his family was in dire straits. One of his brothers became seriously ill, and his mother was ill and dying. She succumbed on July 5, 1929.
In [[Malta]] Pirotta spent two academic years (1928‚Äì30), residing and lecturing at [[Rabat, Malta]]. More or less as usual, Pirotta read philosophy, the history of philosophy, and apologetics. He also continued to publish steadily, especially scientific reviews and articles.
====At Fiesole==== Back in Italy, Pirotta was sent to College of [[Fiesole]], near [[Florence]], [[Italy]]. The college here was not a public one, but the academic institution that prepared [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] students for the [[priesthood]]. Pirotta stayed here for just one academic year (1930/31), reading the history of philosophy, and the treatise on divine revelation.
Here he also worked upon the first of his six-volumed ''Summa Philosoph√¶'' (The Sum of Philosophy), which he published in 1931. He also prepared for his Masters. The final exam was successfully held on May 7, 1931, in [[Rome]] at the [[Angelicum]] College, which by that time had been upgraded to the status of an international university. As was the usual practice, the title was conferred four years later. The official investiture was held at the Dominican Priory at [[Rabat, Malta]] on November 24, 1935.
====At Naples==== After [[Tuscany]] came [[Naples]]. Here, at the [[Aquinas]] College of the [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]], Pirotta did not go simply as a lecturer, but as a Rector (''‚ÄòLectorem Primarium‚Äô''). He stayed here for three consecutive academic years (1931‚Äì34).
At Naples, Pirotta may be considered to have been at the peak of his academic career. At the beginning of his experience there he published the first of his planned six-volumed ''Summa Philosoph√¶'': a study about Aristotelico-Thomistic logic, called the '''''Philosophia Rationalis''''' (Rational Philosophy). Later, he proceeded to publish his third exposition: this time of Aquinas‚Äô commentary on [[Aristotle]]‚Äôs '''''Ethicorum ad Nichomachum''''' (Nichomachean Ethics).
===In Malta=== In 1934, Pirotta was recalled to [[Malta]], at [[Rabat, Malta]]. During the first academic year (1934/35) he was just a lecturer of philosophy. In the following year, however, he was chosen to be the Rector of the college. He retained this office for nine years, up till 1944, which included the worst of the [[World War II]] years in [[Malta]].
At the beginning of the 1935/36 academic year, Pirotta was officially conferred with his Masters. A few months later, he issued his second volume of the ''Summa Philosophi√¶'', the one dealing with natural philosophy, and called '''''Philosophia Naturalis'''''.
In 1938 Pirotta applied for the Deanship of philosophy at the [[Royal University of Malta]]. Though unmatched or much less unsurpassed by any other contender, he lost the competition nonetheless. Though he took the rebuff most gracefully, Pirotta decided to make some drastic changes to his life. Thus, from 1939 onwards, right up to his death, he lived the larger part of his days at [[Naxxar]], staying at his convent at [[Rabat, Malta]] only as little as possible.
At [[Rabat, Malta]] Pirotta was still the Rector, and still read philosophy at the college there. Also from 1939 onwards, he acted as supplementary examiner at the [[Royal University of Malta]]. He further continued to deliver sermons here and there, and even to hear confessions on a regular basis.
===Retirement and death=== Before the war was over, at the end of the academic year of 1943/44, Pirotta ‚Äì now almost fifty years of age ‚Äì was relieved of the post of Rector at [[Rabat, Malta]]. During these years he assiduously worked on his next publication, which eventually had to be his last. This was his fourth exposition, the one on [[Aquinas]]‚Äô eight books of commentaries on [[Aristotle]]‚Äôs '''''De Physico Auditu''''' (Physics). It was published in 1953.
One fatal day in the latter part of 1955, Pirotta became victim of acute cerebral vascular insufficiency due to diabetes and chronic smoking. As a result, his memory had become seriously impaired, and so was his reasoning powers. He died at his parents‚Äô home at [[Naxxar]] on November 16, 1956, a month short of his sixty-second birthday, and buried in the [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] church of Our Lady of the Grotto at [[Rabat, Malta]].
==Works==
===Opus magnum=== * The '''''Summa Philosophi√¶ Aristotelico-Thomistic√¶''''' (The Sum of Aritotelico-Thomistic Philosophy) ‚Äì Pirotta planned to publish six volumes to complete this work. Unfortunately, he only succeeded in publishing just the first two. The other four volumes remained manuscripts in different phases of preparation. Undoubtedly, the works of this large-scale project represent Pirotta‚Äôs philosophical prowess at its very best. ** VOL. I ‚Äì '''''Philosophia Rationalis''''' (Rational Philosophy; 1931) ‚Äì This book in Latin, containing 267 pages (and twelve preliminary pages with Roman enumeration), was published by Marietti of [[Turin]], [[Italy]]. It is the first volume of Pirotta‚Äôs incomplete ''Summa Philosophi√¶'' project. The volume opens with a preface and a general introduction to philosophy; and closes with a chart that shows the classification of the philosophical sciences according to the Aristotelico-Thomistic school of thought. All paragraphs contained in the book are numbered. Essentially, Pirotta‚Äôs ''Rational Philosophy'' is a study about logic. **VOL. II ‚Äì '''''Philosophia Naturalis''''' (Natural Philosophy; 1936) ‚Äì The second volume of the incomplete ''Summa'' project took five years to finalize. This book is also in Latin, as most of Pirotta‚Äôs writings, and contains 820 pages, excluding the eight preliminary pages with Roman enumeration. Like the other volume, it was published with Marietti of [[Turin]], [[Italy]]. The book opens with a foreword to the reader, and an introduction; and concludes with an appendix. All paragraphs contained in the book are numbered. Obviously, the writing deals with natural philosophy. **VOL. III ‚Äì '''''Metaphysica Ostensiva Generalis seu Ontologia''''' (General Demonstrative Metaphysics or Ontology; ''c.''1935-40)<ref>ADR, MSS. A164##1 u 2.</ref> ‚Äì This volume in the series should have begun to present Pirotta‚Äôs work on metaphysics. Unfortunately it was never published, though its manuscript shows that it was in an advanced state of composition. **VOL. IV ‚Äì '''''Metaphysica Ostensiva Specialis: Metaphysica Entis Creati''''' (Specific Demonstrative Metaphysics: the Metaphysics of Created Being; ''c.''1935-40)<ref>ADR, MSS. A165##1 and 2.</ref> ‚Äì Again, this writing, intended to be the fourth volume in a series of six forming the ''Summa Philosophi√¶ Aristotelico-Thomistic√¶'', was never completed. In its present form of preparation it is difficult to say what the complete final product would have been. The extant manuscript has parts that are compete and others that aren‚Äôt. Certainly, whole parts that would have been part of the final version have never been written. The whole manuscript is made up of 580 large folios. **VOL. V ‚Äì '''''Metaphysica Ostensiva Specialis: Metaphysica Entis Increati sive Theologia Naturalis seu Theodicea''''' (Specific Demonstrative Metaphysics: the Metaphysics of Uncreated Being otherwise Natural Theology or Theodicy; ''c.''1935-40)<ref>ADR, MS. A166.</ref>‚Äì Surprisingly, amongst the four incomplete manuscripts of Pirotta‚Äôs ''Summa Philosophi√¶ Aristotelico-Thomistic√¶'', this is the most complete. In fact, though it had to be the fifth volume of the series, the ''Metaphysica Ostensiva Specialis'' is practically all ready to go to the printers. It is a matter of speculation whether Pirotta actually intended to publish this fifth volume before the third and fourth. The manuscript is made up of 569 folios. **VOL. VI ‚Äì '''''Metaphysica Defensiva seu Critica''''' (Explicative Metaphysics or Criteriology; ''c.''1935-40)<ref>ADR, MS. A167#1, #2 u #3.</ref> ‚Äì This is most incomplete of Pirotta‚Äôs series of manuscripts related to his ''Summa Philosophi√¶ Aristotelico-Thomistic√¶''. The philosopher worked very little on it as a whole, though then segments of it are actually finalized. The entirety of the extant manuscript comprises a staggering 1260 large folios. However, due to its undeveloped state of composition it is practically impossible to imagine what the final shape of the work would have taken.
===Commentaries===
The commentaries would represent the main output for a Thomistic intellectual with which he really shows his mettle. Apart of Pirotta‚Äôs two published volumes that were part of his ''Summa Philosophi√¶ Aristotelico-Thomistic√¶'', published in 1931 and 1936 respectively, these commentaries‚Äïespecially the first on the ''De Anima''‚Äïwere in fact the intellectual productions that effectively brought Pirotta most renown.
* '''''Commentarium De Anima''''' ([Aquinas‚Äô] Commentary on [Aristotle‚Äôs] ‚ÄòOn the Soul‚Äô; 1925) ‚Äì This book in Latin, which contains 307 pages (excluding the thirteen preliminary pages enumerated with Roman numerals), was published with Marietti of [[Turin]], [[Italy]]. Its whole title is: ''Sancti Thom√¶ Aquinatis Doctoris Angelici Ord. Pr√¶d. In Aristotelis Librum De Anima Commentarium'' (The Commentary of St. [[Thomas Aquinas]], the Angelic Doctor of the Order of Preachers, on [[Aristotle]]‚Äôs Book ''On the Soul''). The volume is dedicated to Mons. Angelo Portelli O.P., Malta‚Äôs then Auxiliary Bishop. The [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] archive at [[Rabat, Malta]], possesses the galley proofs for a new edition of the work,<ref>ADR, MS. A168.</ref> which, incidentally, was never published. Essentially, Pirotta‚Äôs work is a commentary on [[Aquinas]]‚Äô exposition of [[Aristotle]]‚Äôs ''On the Soul''. * '''''De Sensu et Sensato ‚Äì De Memoria et Reminiscientia''''' ([Aquinas‚Äô Commentary on Aristotle‚Äôs] ‚ÄòOn Sense and Sensibility‚Äô [and] ‚ÄòOn Memory and Remembrance‚Äô; 1928) ‚Äì A book in Latin published with Marietti of [[Turin]], [[Italy]], that comprises nine preliminary pages with Roman enumeration, and a further 158 pages. Its whole title is: ''Sancti Thom√¶ Aquinatis Doctoris Angelici Ord. Pr√¶d. In Aristotelis Libros De Sensu et Sensato De Memoria et Reminiscentia Commentarium'' (The Commentary of St. [[Thomas Aquinas]], the Angelic Doctor of the Order of Preachers, on [[Aristotle]]‚Äôs Books ''On Sense and Sensibility'' [and] ''On Memory and Remembrance''). The book is dedicated to a certain Fortunato De Bono, a Maltese early teacher of Pirotta. Essentially, the writing is an interpretation of [[Aquinas]]‚Äô exposition of [[Aristotle]]‚Äôs two works. * '''''Ethicorum Aristotelis ad Nichomachum''''' ([Aquinas‚Äô Exposition of] Aristotle‚Äôs ‚ÄòNicomachean Ethics‚Äô; 1934) ‚Äì This publication follows on the warm reception given to Pirotta‚Äôs two commentaries on [[Aquinas]]‚Äôs exposition of [[Aristotle]]‚Äôs ''On the Soul'', and ''On Sense'' and ''On Memory''. In the intervening years, Pirotta had also published his first volume of his ''Sum of Philosophy''. This volume of 696 pages, excluding the twenty-four preliminary pages with Romon enumeration, was also published with Marietti of [[Turin]], [[Italy]]. Its whole title reads: ''Sancti Thom√¶ Aquinatis Doctoris Angelici Ord. Pr√¶d. In Decem Libros Ethicorum Aristotelis ad Nicomachum Expositio'' (The Exposition of Saint [[Thomas Aquinas]], Angelic Doctor of the Order of Preachers, on the Ten Books of [[Aristotle]]‚Äôs ''Nicomachean Ethics''). The book is dedicated to Fr. M. S. Gillet O.P., the Master General of the [[Dominican Order|Dominican]]s. * '''''In Octo Libri De Physico Auditu sive Physicorum Aristotelis Commentaria''''' ([Aquinas‚Äô] Eight Books on [Aristotle‚Äôs] ‚ÄòPhysics‚Äô or [Aquinas‚Äô] Commentary of Aristotle‚Äôs ‚ÄòPhysics‚Äô; 1953) ‚Äì This is the last of Pirotta‚Äôs major contributions to scholastic philosophy, published barely three years before his death. The study, obviously in Latin, is made up of 658 pages, and was published by M. D‚ÄôAuria Pontificius Editor of [[Naples]], [[Italy]]. The book is divided into eight books, and then into lectures (''lectio''). The first and second Books contain fifteen lectures each; the third, two less; the fourth, twenty-three; the fifth, ten; the sixth, another thirteen; the seventh, just nine; and the eighth, twenty-three. Basically, Pirotta‚Äôs work is a commentary on [[Aquinas]]‚Äô exposition of Aritotle‚Äôs ''Physics''.
===Articles===
Unlike the commentaries, these articles take up some point or aspect of a particular theme on which Pirotta expands upon. With the exception of the very early ones, published by Pirotta when still at the beginning of his career, the rest are master works that would have been minutely scrutinized by the editorial boards concerned before publication, and furthermore exposed Pirotta‚Äôs intellect to a wide readership within international Thomistic academic circles. After publication, almost all of these articles had been subsequently distributed as separate extracts.

===Scientific reviews===
The following reviews, though interesting in themselves, contain little philosophical value. What they do attest to is the standing Pirotta enjoyed with the various editors of the respective scientific journals who had valued Pirotta‚Äôs proficiency enough so as to consider him an academic and intellectual worthy of passing authoritative judgement on the writings of other reputed Thomists. Pirotta does not disappoint. He showers praise when earned, but certainly does not shy away from lashing out when warranted.

===Manuscripts===
Pirotta‚Äôs manuscripts are invaluable documents, as they attest to his background operational activities, and moreover to the keenness and responsibility with which he undertook any commitment, especially those of a philosophical nature. Most of the following texts are incomplete, as Pirotta had not as yet given them their final finishing. To some he surely intended to add on other material. Nonetheless, even as they stand, these documents can be taken as reliable attestations to Pirotta‚Äôs proficiency of labour, and intensity of thought.

===Sermons===
The following texts are the extant sermons that Pirotta read during his pastoral work. All of them have been probably delivered in Malta, even the Italian ones. Roughly speaking, the Italian orations would have been read to diocesan priests or members of religious orders, and the Maltese ones to the general faithful. Though most of them do not contain any philosophical interest, some of them do bear witness to Pirotta‚Äôs philosophical type of mind, even when treating spiritual or religious matters.
====In Italian====
Pirotta‚Äôs extant sermons in Italian are all collected at the [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] archives at [[Rabat, Malta]]. Most of the titles are Pirotta‚Äôs own.
* ''Domenica Ia d‚ÄôAvvento ‚Äì Conoscere Ges√π Christo'' (1st Sunday of Advent ‚Äì Knowing Jesus Christ; 1937)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#1.</ref> * ''Domenica 2a d‚ÄôAvvento ‚Äì Amare Ges√π Christo'' (2nd Senday of Advent ‚Äì Loving Jesus Christ; 1937)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#2.</ref> * ''Domenica 3a d‚ÄôAvvento ‚Äì Seguire ed imitare Ges√π Christo'' (3rd Sunday of Advent ‚Äì Following and imitating Jesus Christ; 1937)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#3.</ref> * ''Domenica 4a d‚ÄôAvvento ‚Äì Preparare a ricevere degnamente Ges√π Christo'' (4th Sunday of Advent ‚Äì Preparing to receive worthily Jesus Christ; 1937)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#4.</ref> * ''Giorno Io, Predica Ia ‚Äì Il valore dell‚Äôanima umana'' (1st Day, 1st Oration ‚Äì The value of the human soul; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#5.</ref> * ''Giorno IIo, Predica IIa ‚Äì Il peccato mortale'' (2nd Day, 2nd Oration ‚Äì Mortal sin; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#6.</ref> * ''Giorno IIIa, Predica IIIa ‚Äì L‚Äôiniettatore micidiale del male: Il mondo'' (3rd Day, 3rd Oration ‚Äì The deadly originator of evil: The world; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#7.</ref> * ''Giorno IVo, Predica IVa ‚Äì Il formaco del peccato: La confessione'' (4th Day, 4th Oration ‚Äì The remedy of sin: Confession; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#8.</ref> * ''Giorno Vo, Predica Va ‚Äì Pratica ed esercizio delle opere buone'' (5th Day, 5th Oration ‚Äì The use and exercise of good works; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#9.</ref> * ''Giorno VIo, Predica VIa ‚Äì I doveri professionali del proprio stato'' (6th Day, 6th Oration ‚Äì The professional duties of one‚Äôs state; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#10.</ref> * ''Giorno VIIo, Predia VIIa ‚Äì L‚Äôapostolato laico'' (7th Day, 7th Oration ‚Äì Lay apostolate; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#11.</ref> * ''Panegirico di San Tommaso'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of St. Thomas [Aquinas]; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#12.</ref> * ''Panegirico di San Publio Vescovo e Martire'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of [[St. Publius]] [[Bishop]] and [[Martyr]]; [[Floriana]], [[Malta]]; 23 April 1939)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#13.</ref> * ''Panegirico della Conversione di San Paolo Appostolo'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of St. Paul the Apostle; Mdina Cathedral, Malta; 25 January 1940)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#14.</ref> * ''Predica di Maria SS. Desolata'' (Oration on the Blessed Mary of Sorrows; [[Valletta]], Onorati; Good Friday, 15 April 1949)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#15.</ref> * ''Discorso per l‚ÄôUltimo Giorno dell‚ÄôAnno'' (Talk on New Year‚Äôs Eve; 1938)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#16.</ref> * ''Conferenze rinnovazione dell Profesione Religiosa'' (Talks [on the occasion of the] renewal of Religious Vows; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#17.</ref> * ''Panegirico del S. Patriarca Domenico'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of the Patriarch [[St. Dominic]]; Porto Salvo, Valletta, Malta; 4 August 1939)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#18.</ref> * ''San Tommaso d‚ÄôAquino'' (St. [[Thomas Aquinas]]; La Quercia, [[Viterbo]], [[Italy]]; 7 May 1924)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#19.</ref> * ''Sermoni Suore Domenicane'' ([Seven] Sermons to [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] Nuns; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A161#20.</ref>
====In Maltese====
Pirotta‚Äôs extant sermons in Maltese are collected in separate groups of manuscripts (as indicated). They are all kept at the [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] archives at [[Rabat, Malta]]. The titles are generally Pirotta‚Äôs own. * ''Relazioni fuk iz-Zwieg ‚ÄúMixt√¶ Religionis‚Äù'' (Report on mixed marriages; 1913?)<ref>ADR, MS. A172#9.</ref> ‚Äì Presented at the [[Eucharistic Congress]] of the [[diocese]] of [[Malta]] at [[Floriana]] and [[Sliema]]. * ''Panegirico di Maria Assunta in Cielo'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of the Assumption of [the Blessed] Mary in Heaven; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#1.</ref> * ''Panegierku ta San Filep d‚ÄôAgira'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of St. Philip of Hegira; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#2.</ref> * ''Panegierku ta Maria Bambina'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of the Birth of [the Blessed] Mary; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#3.</ref> * ''Panegierku Madonna tad Duttrina'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of Our Lady of Good Teaching; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#4.</ref> * ''Panegierku tal Kalb Imkaddsa ta‚Äô Ges√π'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of the Blessed Heart of Jesus; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#5.</ref> * ''Panegirico del SS.mo Nome di Ges√π ‚Äì L‚Äôeccellenza e le virt√π del SS. Nome'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of the Most Holy Name of Jesus ‚Äì The distinction and virtues of the Most Holy Name [of Jesus]; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#6.</ref> * ''Discorsetto nel Io Mistero Doloroso'' (Short talk on the 1st Mystery of Sorrow [of the [[rosary]]]; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#7.</ref> * ''Discorso nel IIIo e IVo Mistero Doloroso'' (Talk on the 3rd and 4th Mysteries of Sorrow [of the [[rosary]]]; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#8.</ref> * ''Fervorini f‚ÄôJum il Milied'' (Talk for Christmas Day; 1946?)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#9.</ref> * ''Fervorini maghmul fl‚ÄôEwwel Quddiesa tal Milied'' (Talk read at the First Mass of Christmas Day; 1946)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#10.</ref> * ''Diskorso Antiblasfemo'' (Talk against blasphemy; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#11.</ref> * ''Diskorsetto Antiblasfemo'' (Short talk against blasphemy; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#12.</ref> * ''Vangelo ‚Äì Domenica IV Post Oct. Pasch√¶'' (Gospel ‚Äì 4th Sunday after Easter; 1938)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#13.</ref> * ''Vangelo ‚Äì VIII Domenica P. O. Pent.'' (Gospel ‚Äì 8th Sunday after Pentecost; 1938?)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#14.</ref> * ''Vangelo ‚Äì IX Domenica dopo Oct. Pent.'' (Gospel ‚Äì 9th Sunday after Pentecost; 1938?)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#15.</ref> * ''Vangelo ‚Äì Domenica XXI P. O. P.'' (Gospel ‚Äì 21st Sunday after Pentecost 1938?)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#16.</ref> * ''Fervorino Eucharistico in occasione della festa di San Luigi Gonzaga'' (Eucharistic talk on the occasion of the feast of [[St. Louis Gonzaga]]; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#17.</ref> * ''Siegha ta Adorazzjoni'' (One hour adoration; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#18.</ref> * ''Panigierku tal Madonna tar Ruzarju'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of Our Lady of the [[Rosary]]; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#19.</ref> * ''Panigierku ta San Duminku'' (Laudatory discourse [in honour] of [[St. Dominic]]; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#20.</ref> * ''Priedki fuq il Patrijarka San Duminku ‚Äì San Domenico e il suo Ordine'' (Orations on the Patriarch [[St. Dominic]] ‚Äì [[St. Dominic]] and his Order; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#21.</ref> * ''Diskors ghall Ewwel Quddiesa Solenni ta‚Äô Sacerdot gdid'' (Talk for the First Solemn Mass of a new [[Priest]]; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#22.</ref> * ''Prietca ta tielet misteru Glorioso'' (Oration on the 3rd Glorious mystery [of the [[rosary]]]; 1916)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#23.</ref> * ''Prietca 4o ‚Äì 5o Glorioso'' (Oration [on the] 4th [and] 5th Glorious [mystery [of the [[rosary]]]; 1916?)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#24.</ref> * ''Ferrvorino Eucaristico'' (Eucharistic talk; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A162#25.</ref> * ''Irtir Spirituali: Primo Giorno ‚Äì Eccellenza e prezzo dell‚Äôanima'' (Spiritual retreat: 1st Day ‚Äì The distinction and worth of the soul; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#1.</ref> * ''Irtir Spirituali: Secondo Giorno ‚Äì Dovere dell‚Äôanima verso Dio'' (Spiritual retreat: 2nd Day ‚Äì The duties of the soul towards God; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#2.</ref> * ''Irtir Spirituali: Terzo Giorno ‚Äì L‚Äôamore del prossimo'' (Spiritual retreat: 3rd Day ‚Äì Love of neighbour; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#3.</ref> * ''Irtir Spirituali: Quarto Giorno'' (Spiritual retreat: 4th day; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#4.</ref> * ''Irtir Spirituali: Quinto Giorno'' (Spiritual retreat: 5th Day; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#5.</ref> * ''Irtir Spirituali: Sesto Giorno ‚Äì Il sacrificio S. Messa'' (Spiritual retreat: 6th Day ‚Äì The sacrifice of the Mass; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#6.</ref> * ''Irtir Spirituali: Ottavo ed Ultimo ‚Äì La perseveranza Cristiana'' (Spiritual retreat: 8th and last ‚Äì Christian perseverance; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#7.</ref> * ''Barka tas Salib fl ahhar tal Ezercizzi {{Not a typo|jew}} tal Irtir Spirituali'' (Blessing at the end of the [spiritual] Exercises or Spiritual Retreat; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#8.</ref> * ''Scheme di Conferenze Della Perfezione Religiosa o del Profitto Spirituale'' (Schemes for talks on the Fulfilment of Religious [life] or on Spiritual Rewards; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#9.</ref> * ''Skema ta Ezercizzi Spirituali'' (Scheme of Spiritual Exercises; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#10.</ref> * ''Diskors fuq is Sagrament tal Krar'' (Talk on the Sacrament of Confession; undated)<ref>ADR, MS. A163#11.</ref> * ''Elogiu Funebri al meut tal Papa Piu XI'' (Talk for the memorial service of [[Pope Pius XI]]; 1939)<ref>ADR, MS. A172#1.</ref>
==Appreciation== Pirotta was the last of major philosophers within the school of [[Scholasticism]]. With him, an era of Scholastics, extending back to the latter part of the 16th century, starting with [[John Matthew Rispoli]], came to an end. Today, as philosophy took new shapes and adopted different language-forms, Pirotta might appear almost incomprehensible in his world-view and philosophical method. This is further intensified his consistent use of Latin, a language very few still remember how to use or read.
Though a great speculative thinker, it is somewhat difficult to gauge Pirotta‚Äôs originality. Surely his lack of concrete commitment with things social and political, as any old-time, first division scholastic would be, today makes him suspect of a certain lack of concern for world affairs as for the fate of humans. However, the scholastics had another way of understanding what philosophical service to humankind should be. Arguably, they sought to enlighten the highest (or most profound) aspects of reason, there where the quality of life might be improved and perfected.
Much work is still needed to continue discovering the wealth which philosophers of the calibre of Pirotta possessed.
==See also== * [[Philosophy in Malta]]
==References== {{Reflist|3}}
==Sources== * Mark Montebello, ''Il-Ktieb tal-Filosofija f‚ÄôMalta'' (''A Source Book of Philosophy in Malta''), PIN Publications, Malta, 2001. * Mark Montebello, ''Angelo Pirotta: A Maltese philosopher of the first water'', Maltese Dominican Province, Malta, 2006.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pirotta, Angelo}} [[Category:Maltese philosophers]] [[Category:20th-century philosophers]] [[Category:Maltese educational theorists]] [[Category:Maltese academics]] [[Category:Maltese educators]] [[Category:People from Naxxar]] [[Category:1894 births]] [[Category:1956 deaths]]

[[File:Oude stadhuis aan de Groenmarkt in Den Haag (20).JPG|thumb|Decorative 18th century door piece from the [[Vierschaar]] (city tribunal) in [[Old City Hall (The Hague)|City Hall of The Hague]], by [[Jacob de Wit]], illustrating {{lang|la|audi alteram partem}}.]] {{italic title}} '''{{lang|la|Audi alteram partem}}''' (or '''{{lang|la|audiatur et altera pars}}''') is a [[Latin]] [[List of Latin phrases|phrase]] meaning "listen to the other side", or "let the other side be heard as well".<ref>[http://www.m-w.com/dictionary/audi+alteram+partem audi alteram partem: Definition from the Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary]</ref> It is the principle that no person should be judged without a fair hearing in which each party is given the opportunity to respond to the evidence against them.<ref>[http://www.duhaime.org/LegalDictionary/A/Audialterampartem.aspx Audi alteram partem's entry in the duhaime.org legal dictionary]</ref>
"Audi alteram partem" is considered to be a principle of [[fundamental justice]] or [[Equity (law)|equity]] or the principle of natural justice in most [[legal system]]s. This principle includes the rights of a party or his lawyers to confront the [[witness]]es against him, to have a fair opportunity to challenge the [[evidence (law)|evidence]] presented by the other party, to summon one's own witnesses and to present evidence, and to have counsel, if necessary at public expense, in order to make one's case properly.
The phrase has come to be used as the motto for various political and judicial organisations, and is also the origin of the name of the German carmaker [[Audi]].
==History of use== As a general principle of rationality in reaching conclusions in disputed matters, "Hear both sides" was treated as part of common wisdom by the [[Ancient Greece|ancient Greek]] dramatists.<ref>e.g. [[Aeschylus]], ''[[The Eumenides]]'' 431, 435</ref> A similar principle can also be found in Islamic law, based on a [[hadith]] indicating that in litigation, both parties must be heard.<ref> Imam Abu Dawud. 2008. ''Sunan Abu Dawud Vol. 3 (Translated to English by Ahmad Hasan)''. Riyadh: Darussalam,, Hadith No. 3575, Grade: Hasan </ref> The principle was referred to by the [[International Court of Justice]] in the ''Nuclear Tests'' case, referring to [[France]]'s non-appearance at judgment.<ref>''[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/58/6093.pdf Nuclear Tests (Australia c. France)]'', C. I. J., December 20, 1974, p. 265</ref> Modern legal systems differ on whether individuals can be convicted ''[[trial in absentia|in absentia]]''. The principle is used in [[labour law]] matters in countries like South Africa and Zimbabwe.
==Other uses==
The Political Interest Society of the [[University of Melbourne]] uses the phrase as its motto.<ref>http://umsu.unimelb.edu.au/clubs/political-interest-society/</ref> The All-Campus Judicial Council of the [[University of Rochester]] has used the phrase as its motto since 2001.<ref>http://sa.rochester.edu/sa/acjc/</ref>
The phrase is also the origin of the name of [[Germany|German]] carmaker [[Audi]]. Founder [[August Horch]] had left his previous company, [[Motorwagenwerke]], after a dispute with partners and founded a new company on 16 July 1909, initially named the ''August Horch Automobilwerke GmbH''. His former partners sued him for trademark infringement, and the German [[Reichsgericht]] (Supreme Court) ruled that the Horch brand belonged to his former company.<ref name="chronicle2">[http://www.audiusa.com/us/brand/en/about/main/history.html Audi History] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100209000116/http://www.audiusa.com/us/brand/en/about/main/history.html |date=9 February 2010 }} audiusa.com</ref> Horch therefore called a meeting with close business friends Paul and Franz Fikentscher, to come up with a new name for the company. During this meeting, Franz's son was quietly studying Latin in a corner of the room. Several times he looked like he was on the verge of saying something but would just swallow his words and continue working, until he finally blurted out, "Father ‚Äì ''audiatur et altera pars''... wouldn't it be a good idea to call it ''audi'' instead of ''horch''?"<ref>August Horch: "Ich baute Autos ‚Äì Vom Schmiedelehrling zum Autoindustriellen", Sch√ºtzen-Verlag Berlin 1937</ref> "Horch!" in German means "Hark!" or "hear", which is "Audi" in the singular imperative form of "audire" ‚Äì "to listen" ‚Äì in Latin. The idea was enthusiastically accepted by everyone attending the meeting, and the company was registered as ''Audi Automobilwerke GmbH Zwickau'' in 1910.<ref>{{cite book | title = A History of Progress ‚Äì Chronicle of the Audi AG | publisher=Audi AG, Public Relations | year = 1996 | page = 30 | url = http://www.bentleypublishers.com/product.htm?code=gahp | isbn = 0-8376-0384-6}}</ref>
==See also== *{{lang|la|[[Nemo iudex in causa sua]]}} *[[Right of reply]] *[[Trial in absentia|Trial ''in absentia'']]
==References== <references/>

{{Infobox person |name = Sebastiaan (Bas) Haring |image = File:Bas Haring 03.JPG |caption = Bas Haring |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1968|4|23|df=y}} |nationality = Dutch |known_for = Philosopher, writer, professor }} [[File:Bas Haring - De IJzeren Wil.jpg|thumb|Bas Haring reading from ''De IJzeren Wil'' (''The Iron Will''), 2007]]
'''Sebastiaan (Bas) Haring''' / '''Prof.dr. S. Haring''' (born 23 April 1968 in [[De Bilt]]) is a [[The Netherlands|Dutch]] [[philosopher]], writer of [[popular science]] and [[children's literature]], [[television presenter]] and [[professor]]. He's a full professor at Leiden University where he holds a chair in ‚Äúpublic understanding of science‚Äù since 2007.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://mediatechnology.leiden.edu/people/staff/bas-haring|title = Haring, Bas - Media Technology MSc Programme - Leiden University|website = mediatechnology.leiden.edu|access-date = 2016-03-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.universiteitleiden.nl/en/staffmembers/bas-haring|title = Bas Haring - Leiden University|website = Leiden University|language = en-US|access-date = 2016-03-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.leidenuniv.nl/nieuwsarchief2/1146.html|title=Universiteit Leiden|website=www.leidenuniv.nl|access-date=2016-03-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.universiteitvannederland.nl/college/hoe-kun-je-op-de-wc-uitgroeien-tot-groot-filosoof/|title=Hoe kun je op de wc uitgroeien tot groot filosoof? {{!}} Universiteit van Nederland|website=Universiteit van Nederland (Dutch)|access-date=2016-03-08}}</ref> He also hosted his own philosophical tv-program for Dutch public broadcasting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tvblik.nl/dossier/bas-haring|title=Bas Haring|website=TVblik (Dutch)|access-date=2016-03-08}}</ref> In his work his aims are to make science more accessible for a general public.<ref name=":0" /> Haring tries to make others think about simple and complex issues. To make his questions, positions and point of views clear, he's known for using humor, personal stories, and analogies between animals, people and computers. And his name is like a dutch fish.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kb.nl/themas/filosofie/bas-haring|title=Bas Haring {{!}} Koninklijke Bibliotheek|website=www.kb.nl (Dutch)|access-date=2016-03-08}}</ref>
Haring first achieved prominence with his 2001 children's book ''[[Bas Haring#Cheese and the Theory of Evolution|Cheese and the Theory of Evolution]]'' in which he explained [[evolution]] and its implications. The book received several awards and has been translated into ten different languages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nwo.nl/actueel/evenementen/eurekaprijs/eerdere+edities|title=Eerdere edities Eurekaprijs|last=Marianne|website=www.nwo.nl|access-date=2016-03-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309094643/http://www.nwo.nl/actueel/evenementen/eurekaprijs/eerdere+edities|archivedate=2016-03-09|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.2015.goudenboekenuil.be/edities|title=Edities {{!}} Gouden Boekenuil|website=www.2015.goudenboekenuil.be|access-date=2016-03-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310181124/http://www.2015.goudenboekenuil.be/edities|archive-date=2016-03-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cheese and the Theory of Evolution (Kaas en de evolutietheorie)''An informative literary jewel''|author=Pjotr van Lenteren|url=http://www.productiefonds.nl/book/book2.php?show=all&book_vertid=2871&Book=129|accessdate=2007-12-18}}</ref> His book ''For a Successful Life'' was published in 2008 by Beautiful Books Limited (UK).
== Bibliography == * Cheese and the Theory of Evolution (2001) (only available in Dutch, not in English) * The Iron Will (2003) * Media technology (2007) * For a Successful Life: A Plea for the Unsuccessful Life (2008) (Beautiful Books Limited) * The Aquarium of Walter Huijsmans (2009) * Why? (2009) * Falling Quarters. -A smart selection of readable science''.'' (Along with Ionica Smeets, 2010) * The Consciousness (2010) * Plastic pandas (2011)
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.basharing.com/ Official page (Dutch)] * [http://tvblik.nl/dossier/bas-haring Dutch television archives (Dutch)] {{Authority control}}

{{Use Indian English|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} [[File:Swami Vivekananda Jaipur.jpg|thumb|230px|Swami Vivekananda]] '''[[Swami Vivekananda]]''' (1863‚Äì1902)<ref name="Chaube p52">{{Harvnb|Chaube|2005|p=52}}</ref> was an Indian Hindu monk and a key figure in the introduction of Indian philosophies of [[Vedanta]] and [[Yoga]] to the western world.<ref name="Vivekananda 2006 p11">{{Harvnb|Vivekananda|2006|p=11}}</ref> He was one of the most influential philosophers and social reformers in his contemporary India and the most successful and influential missionaries of Vedanta to the Western world.<ref name="Mohapatra p14">{{Harvnb|Mohapatra|2009|p=14}}</ref><ref name="Piazza p59">{{Harvnb|Piazza|1978|p=59}}</ref> Indian Nobel laureate poet [[Rabindranath Tagore]]'s suggested to study the works of Vivekananda to understand India. He also told, in Vivekananda there was nothing negative, but everything positive.<ref name="Chattopadhyaya p314" />
In last one century, hundreds of scholarly books have been written on Vivekananda, his works and his philosophy in different languages. [[Sister Nivedita]], who was a disciple and a friend of Vivekananda, wrote two books ''[[The Master as I Saw Him]]'' and ''[[Notes of some wanderings with the Swami Vivekananda]]''. The first one was published in 1910 and the second one was published in 1913.<ref name="Chattopadhyaya p299">{{Harvnb|Chattopadhyaya|1999|p=299}}</ref> [[Sister Gargi]]'s lifelong research work, a series of six volumes of books, ''[[Swami Vivekananda in the West: New Discoveries]]'' was first published in two volumes in 1957. In 1983-87 these series was republished in six volumes.<ref name="Chattopadhyaya p326">{{Harvnb|Chattopadhyaya|1999|p=326}}</ref> Bengali scholar and critic Sankari Prasad Basu, who was a director of Swami Vivekananda Archives, [[Ramakrishna Mission Institute of Culture]] wrote several books on Vivekananda such as ''Vivekananda o Samakalin Bharatbarsha'' ({{Bn icon}} 7 volumes), ''Sahasya Vivekananda'' {{Bn icon}}, ''Bandhu Vivekananda'' {{Bn icon}} etc.<ref name="Dutt p121">{{Harvnb|Dutt|1999|p=121}}</ref>
Monks of Ramakrishna Math and Mission too have written several notable books on the life and works of Vivekananda. ''Swami Vivekananda and Modern India'' written by Swami Jagadiswarananda was first published in 1941. In this book the author covered the biography of Vivekananda in brief.<ref name="Chattopadhyaya p314">{{Harvnb|Chattopadhyaya|1999|p=314}}</ref> [[Swami Nikhilananda]] wrote ''Vivekananda: A Biography'' which was first published in 1943 from [[Advaita Ashrama]].<ref name="Chattopadhyaya p316">{{Harvnb|Chattopadhyaya|1999|p=316}}</ref> ''Yuganayak Vivekananda'' {{Bn icon}}, written by [[Swami Gambhirananda]] was first published in 1966‚Äì1967.<ref name="Chattopadhyaya p326" />
== Books == ;Published in his lifetime<ref name="Vivekananda Library online Works">{{cite web|title=Vivekananda Library online|url=http://www.vivekananda.net/BooksBySwami.html|publisher=vivekananda.net|accessdate=12 December 2012}}</ref> * ''[[Karma Yoga (book)|Karma Yoga]]'' (1896) * ''[[Raja Yoga (book)|Raja Yoga]]'' (1896) * ''[[Vedanta Philosophy: An address before the Graduate Philosophical Society]]'' (first published 1896) * ''[[Lectures from Colombo to Almora]]'' (1897) * ''Vedanta philosophy: lectures on Jnana Yoga'' (1902)

S.|title=Encyclopaedia of Eminent Thinkers: The political thought of Vivekananda|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ADEddk9V9w0C&pg=PA7|year=1998|publisher=Concept Publishing Company|isbn=978-81-7022-709-0}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|last=Chaube|first=Sarayu Prasad|title=Recent Philosophies On Education On India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jf4RxehpiewC&pg=PA52|year=2005|publisher=Concept Publishing Company|isbn=978-81-8069-216-1}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|last=Vivekananda|first=Swami|title=The Indispensable Vivekananda: An Anthology for Our Times|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=usBhrZcnJ78C|accessdate=8 July 2013|year=2006|publisher=Orient Blackswan|isbn=978-81-7824-130-2}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|last=Mohapatra|first=Amulya Ranjan|title=Swaraj - Thoughts of Gandhi, Tilak, Aurobindo, Raja Rammohun Roy, Tagore & Vivekananda|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QGgF5HeIBOgC&pg=PA14|year=2009|publisher=Readworthy|isbn=978-81-89973-82-7|pages=14‚Äì}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|last=Piazza|first=Paul|title=Christopher Isherwood: Myth and Anti-Myth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JyoPkIUAnIIC&pg=PA59|year=1978|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-51358-6}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|last=Chattopadhyaya|first=Rajagopal|title=Swami Vivekananda in India: A Corrective Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EtcoeaQIQdAC&pg=PA299|year=1999|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ.|isbn=978-81-208-1586-5}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|last=Dutt|first=Kartik Chandra|title=Who's who of Indian Writers, 1999: A-M|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QA1V7sICaIwC&pg=PA121|year=1999|publisher=Sahitya Akademi|isbn=978-81-260-0873-5}}
== External links == * [http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=su%3AVivekananda+%28Swami+%3B+1863-1902%29&qt=hot_subject Books on Swami Vivekananda in WorldCat] * [http://advaitaashrama.org/Book/Search/Category=Swami%20Vivekananda Books on and by Swami Vivekananda from Advaita Ashrama]

revision.text:
{{short description|A set of morphological features common to members of a phylum of animals}} [[File:Animal diversity.png|thumb|upright=1.3|Modern groups of animals can be grouped by the arrangement of their body structures, so are said to possess different body plans.]]
A '''body plan''', '''''Bauplan''''' (German plural '''''Baupl√§ne'''''), or '''ground plan''' is a set of morphological features common to many members of a [[phylum]] of [[animal]]s.<ref name=Valentine2004>{{cite book |author1=Valentine |first1=James W. |title=On the Origin of Phyla |year=2004 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DMBkmHm5fe4C |isbn=978-0226845487 |page=33}}</ref> The vertebrate body plan is one of many: invertebrates consist of many phyla.
This term, usually applied to animals, envisages a "blueprint" encompassing aspects such as [[symmetry (biology)|symmetry]], [[segmentation (biology)|segmentation]] and [[Limb (anatomy)|limb]] disposition. [[Evolutionary developmental biology]] seeks to explain the origins of diverse body plans.
Body plans have historically been considered to have evolved in a flash in the [[Cambrian explosion]], but a more nuanced understanding of animal evolution suggests gradual development of body plans throughout the early [[Palaeozoic]].
==History== The history of the discovery of body plans can be seen as a movement from a worldview centred on the [[vertebrates]], to seeing the vertebrates (or [[chordate]]s) as one [[phylum]]'s body plan among many. Among the pioneering [[zoologist]]s, Linnaeus identified two body plans outside the vertebrates; Cuvier identified three; and Haeckel had four, as well as the Protista with eight more, for a total of twelve. For comparison, the number of phyla recognised by modern zoologists has risen to 36.<ref name=Valentine2004/>
===Linnaeus, 1735=== <!---[[File:Linnaeus - Regnum Animale (1735).png|thumb|200px|right|[[Linnaeus]]'s table of the Animal Kingdom (''{{lang|la|Regnum Animale}}'') in ''[[Systema Naturae|Systema Natur√¶]]'' (1735)]]---> In his 1735 book, ''[[Systema Naturae|Systema Natur√¶]]'', the Swedish [[botanist]] [[Linnaeus]] grouped the animals into [[quadrupeds]], [[birds]], "amphibians" (including [[tortoises]], [[lizards]] and [[snakes]]), [[fish]], "insects" (Insecta, in which he included [[arachnids]], [[crustaceans]] and [[centipedes]]) and "worms" (Vermes). Linnaeus's Vermes included effectively all other groups of animals, not only [[tapeworms]], [[earthworms]] and [[leeches]] but [[molluscs]], [[sea urchins]] and [[starfish]], [[jellyfish]], [[squid]] and [[cuttlefish]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Linnaeus |first=Carolus |year=1735 |title=Systema naturae, sive regna tria naturae systematice proposita per classes, ordines, genera, & species |pages=1‚Äì12 |location=Leiden |publisher=Haak |url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/15373}}</ref>
===Cuvier, 1817=== [[File:Haeckel arbol bn.png|thumb|200px|right|[[Haeckel]]'s 'Monophyletischer Stambaum der Organismen' from ''Generelle Morphologie der Organismen'' (1866) with the three branches [[Plantae]], [[Protista]], [[Animalia]]]] In his 1817 work, ''Le R√®gne Animal'', the French zoologist [[Georges Cuvier]] combined evidence from comparative anatomy and [[palaeontology]]<ref name="Reiss2009">{{cite book |last=Reiss |first=John |title=Not by Design: Retiring Darwin's Watchmaker |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R5bMCUU0tP0C&pg=PA108 |year=2009 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-94440-4 |page=108}}</ref> to divide the animal kingdom into four body plans. Taking the [[central nervous system]] as the main organ system which controlled all the others, such as the circulatory and digestive systems, Cuvier distinguished four body plans or ''embranchements'':<ref name=DeWit>De Wit, Hendrik Cornelius Dirk De Wit. ''Histoire du D√©veloppement de la Biologie'', Volume III, Presses Polytechniques et Universitaires Romandes, Lausanne, 1994, p. 94-96. {{ISBN|2-88074-264-1}}</ref>
* I. with a brain and a spinal cord (surrounded by skeletal elements)<ref name=DeWit/> * II. with organs linked by nerve fibres<ref name=DeWit/> * III. with two longitudinal, ventral nerve cords linked by a band with two ganglia below the oesophagus<ref name=DeWit/> * IV. with a diffuse nervous system, not clearly discernible<ref name=DeWit/>
Grouping animals with these body plans resulted in four branches: [[vertebrates]], [[molluscs]], [[articulata hypothesis|articulata]] (including [[insects]] and [[annelids]]) and zoophytes or [[radiata]].
===Haeckel, 1866=== [[Ernst Haeckel]], in his 1866 ''Generelle Morphologie der Organismen'', asserted that all living things were [[monophyletic]] (had a single evolutionary origin), being divided into plants, protista, and animals. His protista were divided into moneres, protoplasts, flagellates, diatoms, myxomycetes, myxocystodes, rhizopods, and sponges. His animals were divided into groups with distinct body plans: he named these [[phylum|phyla]]. Haeckel's animal phyla were [[coelenterates]], [[echinoderms]], and (following Cuvier) articulates, molluscs, and vertebrates.<ref>Haeckel, Ernst. ''Generelle Morphologie der Organismen : allgemeine Grundz√ºge der organischen Formen-Wissenschaft, mechanisch begr√ºndet durch die von Charles Darwin reformirte Descendenz-Theorie.'' (1866) Berlin</ref>
===Gould, 1979===
[[Stephen J. Gould]] explored the idea that the different phyla could be perceived in terms of a Bauplan, illustrating their fixity. However, he later abandoned this idea in favor of [[punctuated equilibrium]].<ref>Bowler, Peter J. (2009). ''Evolution: the History of an Idea''. California, p. 364.</ref> <!--later zoologists ...--> <!-- Morphology: ... Turing ... -->
== Origin == 20 out of the 36 body plans originated in the [[Cambrian]] period,<ref name=AmSci>{{cite journal|last1=Erwin |first1=Douglas |last2=Valentine |first2=James |last3=Jablonski |first3=David|title=Recent fossil finds and new insights into animal development are providing fresh perspectives on the riddle of the explosion of animals during the Early Cambrian |journal=American Scientist |date=1997 |issue=March‚ÄìApril |url=http://www.americanscientist.org/issues/num2/the-origin-of-animal-body-plans/3}}</ref> in the "[[Cambrian explosion]]",<ref name="Erwin1999">{{Cite journal | last1 = Erwin | first1 = D. H. | title = The Origin of Bodyplans | doi = 10.1093/icb/39.3.617 | journal = Integrative and Comparative Biology | volume = 39 | issue = 3 | pages = 617‚Äì629 | year = 1999 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> However, complete body plans of many [[Phylum|phyla]] emerged much later, in the [[Palaeozoic]] or beyond.<ref name="Budd2000">{{cite journal |last1=Budd |first1=G. E. |last2=Jensen |first2=S. |year=2000 |title=A critical reappraisal of the fossil record of the bilaterian phyla |volume=75 |issue=2 |pages=253‚Äì95 |journal=Biological Reviews of the Cambridge Philosophical Society |doi=10.1111/j.1469-185X.1999.tb00046.x |pmid=10881389 }}</ref>
The current range of body plans is far from exhaustive of the possible patterns for life: the [[Precambrian]] [[Ediacara biota|Ediacaran biota]] includes body plans that differ from any found in currently living organisms, even though the overall arrangement of unrelated modern taxa is quite similar.<ref>{{Cite journal| last1 = Antcliffe | first1 = J. B.| last2 = Brasier | first2 = M. D.| title = Charnia and sea pens are poles apart| journal = Journal of the Geological Society| volume = 164| pages = 49| year = 2007| doi = 10.1144/0016-76492006-080| url = https://oxford.academia.edu/MartinBrasier/Papers/416927/Charnia_and_Sea_Pens_Are_Poles_Apart<!--free access-->}}</ref> Thus the Cambrian explosion appears to have more or less completely replaced the earlier range of body plans.<ref name=AmSci/>
== Genetic basis == {{further|evolutionary developmental biology|morphogenesis}}
[[Gene]]s, [[embryo]]s and development together determine the form of an adult organism's body, through the complex switching processes involved in [[morphogenesis]].
Developmental biologists seek to understand how genes control the development of structural features through a cascade of processes in which key genes produce [[morphogen]]s, chemicals that diffuse through the body to produce a gradient that acts as a position indicator for cells, turning on other genes, some of which in turn produce other morphogens. A key discovery was the existence of groups of [[homeobox|homeobox genes]], which function as switches responsible for laying down the basic body plan in animals. The homeobox genes are remarkably conserved between species as diverse as the fruit fly and humans, the basic segmented pattern of the worm or fruit fly being the origin of the segmented spine in humans. The field of animal [[evolutionary developmental biology]] ('Evo Devo'), which studies the genetics of [[Morphology (biology)|morphology]] in detail, is rapidly expanding<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?articleID=0005D708-2F7C-123B-AF7C83414B7F0000 | title=Evo Devo is the New Buzzword... | author=Hall, Brian K. | date=28 March 2005 | accessdate=13 September 2014}}</ref> with many of the developmental genetic cascades, particularly in the fruit fly ''[[Drosophila]]'', catalogued in considerable detail.<ref name="Wallace">{{cite book |last=Arthur |first=Wallace. |authorlink=Wallace Arthur |year=1997 |title=Animal Body Plans |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge England|isbn=0-521-77928-6}}</ref>
== See also == {{portal|Evolutionary biology|Paleontology}} {{Div col}}<!-- Many of these terms need desperately to be incorporated into the body of the article as vital bits of the explanation, linked, and referenced --> * {{annotated link|Anatomical terms of location}} * {{annotated link|Arthropod head problem}} * {{annotated link|Deep homology}} * {{annotated link|Evolutionary developmental biology}} * {{annotated link|Phylum#Definition based on body plan|Definition of Phylum based on body plan}} * {{annotated link|Ediacaran biota}} * {{annotated link|Macroevolution}} * {{annotated link|Precambrian body plans}} * {{annotated link|Sean B. Carroll}} * {{annotated link|Segmentation (biology)}} * {{annotated link|Supernumerary body part}} * {{annotated link|Symmetry in biology}} {{div col end}}
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == <!-- Please DO ''not'' add new external links! Instead please submit them on the Talk page for discussion about their proposed inclusion. Thank you. --> * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080508074233/http://8e.devbio.com/article.php?id=117 Developmental Biology 8e Online: Patterning of the Mesoderm by Activin]
;Videos * [http://video.on.nytimes.com/?fr_story=3ba8ecaed1cf130c1d0ea4baa3876356bea3bb58 The Science of Evolution: Sean B. Carroll explains the genetics of the fruit fly body plan.]
