revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} [[File:Barbora Balkova EveAdamIdealniSituaceBudemeVsichniSpat2006.jpg|thumb|A family together in a bed]] '''Co-sleeping''' is a practice in which babies and young [[child]]ren [[sleep]] close to one or both [[parenting|parents]], as opposed to in a separate room. Co-sleeping individuals sleep in sensory proximity to one another, where the individual senses the presence of others.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = http://cosleeping.nd.edu/videos/|title = Television and Documentary Videos|date = 2005|accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = McKenna (speaker)|first = J}}</ref> This sensory proximity can either be triggered by touch, smell, taste, or noise. Therefore, the individuals can be a few centimeters away or on the other side of the room and still have an effect on the other.<ref name=":2" /> It is standard practice in many parts of the world, and is practiced by a significant minority in countries where cribs are also used.
'''Bed-sharing''', a practice in which babies and young children sleep in the same bed with one or both parents, is a subset of co-sleeping. Co-bedding refers to infants (typically twins or higher-order multiples) sharing the same bed.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Lifespan development: A chronological approach|last = Hoffnung|first = M|publisher = |isbn = |location = Milton, Qld|pages = }}</ref> There are conflicting views on bed-sharing [[#Safety and health|safety and health]] compared to using a separate infant bed.
The [[American Academy of Pediatrics]] does encourage room-sharing (sleeping in the same room but on separate surfaces) in its policy statement regarding [[sudden infant death syndrome|SIDS]] prevention, but it recommends against bed-sharing with infants.<ref name="pediatrics.aappublications.org">{{cite web|url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/128/5/1030.abstract?sid=ffa523b4-9b5d-492c-a3d1-80de22504e1d| title= SIDS and Other Sleep-Related Infant Deaths: Expansion of Recommendations for a Safe Infant Sleeping Environment | accessdate= 16 November 2011}}</ref><ref name="Kemp, James S. 2000">Kemp, James S. et al. (2000) [http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/content/full/106/3/e41 Unsafe Sleep Practices and an Analysis of Bedsharing Among Infants Dying Suddenly and Unexpectedly]: Results of a Four-Year, Population-Based, Death-Scene Investigation Study of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome and Related Deaths. PEDIATRICS Vol. 106 No. 3 September 2000, p. e41</ref>
Recent legal rulings suggest that bed-sharing has been attributed as a factor of unintentional infant suffocation. For instance, parents under the influence of drugs or alcohol and whose children died while bed-sharing have been charged and, at times, prosecuted with manslaughter<ref name = murder/> in several US states (including Minnesota,<ref>{{cite news|title=Drunk father rolled on top of his 7-week-old baby boy and killed him after a night drinking to celebrate his anniversary|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2573503/Drunk-father-rolled-7-week-old-baby-boy-suffocated-night-drinking-celebrate-anniversary.html|accessdate=20 December 2017|publisher=Daily Mail|date=4 March 2014}}</ref> Michigan,<ref>{{cite web|title=Mich. Mom Charged with Involuntary Manslaughter After Baby Suffocates While Sleeping with Her in Bed|url=http://people.com/crime/michigan-mom-baby-suffocates-manslaughter/|website=People|publisher=Time, Inc.|accessdate=20 December 2017|date=19 September 2017}}</ref> Georgia,<ref>{{cite web|title=''Bohannon v. State'', 498 SE 2d 316, 230 Ga. App. 829 (1998)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=80000006|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> Pennsylvania,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Barbara|title='Don't sleep with your kid': DA after mom charged in baby smothering death|url=http://www.pennlive.com/news/2017/05/post_122.html|accessdate=20 December 2017|agency=Penn Live|publisher=PA Media Group|date=25 May 2017}}</ref> Texas,<ref>{{cite news|title=Mom charged with involuntary manslaughter after baby found dead, naked on Christmas Eve|url=http://www.kptv.com/story/30847906/mom-charged-with-involuntary-manslaughter-after-baby-found-dead-naked-on-christmas-eve|accessdate=20 December 2017|agency=Fox 12 Oregon|date=29 December 2015}}</ref> Wisconsin<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flynt|first1=Jeff|title=Mom Arrested in Co-Sleeping Death|url=http://wtaq.com/news/articles/2016/nov/18/mom-arrested-in-co-sleeping-death/|accessdate=20 December 2017|agency=WTAQ|date=18 November 2016}}</ref> and Utah.<ref name = murder>{{cite web|url=http://www.sheknows.com/parenting/articles/852667/co-sleeping-parents-charged-with-murder| title= Co-sleeping parents charged with murder | accessdate= 12 May 2012}}</ref>
==Introduction== [[File:Zeichnung Schlafen ElmarErsch.jpg|thumb|right|A child lies in the arms of his father.]] Bed-sharing is standard practice in many parts of the world outside of [[North America]], [[Europe]] and [[Australia]], and even in the latter areas a significant minority of children have shared a bed with their parents at some point in childhood. One 2006 study of children age 3‚Äì10 in [[India]] reported 93% of children bed-sharing<ref>{{Cite journal|last2=Malhi|first2=P|last3=Kashyap|first3=S|year=2006|title=Patterns and problems of sleep in school going children|journal=Indian pediatrics|volume=43|issue=1|pages=35‚Äì8|pmid=16465004|author1=Bharti|first1=B}}</ref> while a 2006 study of children in [[Kentucky]] in the [[United States]] reported 15% of [[infants]] and [[toddlers]] 2 weeks to 2 years engage in bed-sharing.<ref>{{Cite journal|last2=Gozal|first2=D|year=2006|title=Sleep habits and risk factors for sleep-disordered breathing in infants and young toddlers in Louisville, Kentucky|journal=Sleep Medicine|volume=7|issue=3|pages=211‚Äì9|doi=10.1016/j.sleep.2005.11.003|pmid=16564742|author1=Montgomery-Downs|first1=H. E.}}</ref>
Bed-sharing was widely practiced in all areas up to the 19th century, until the advent of giving the child his or her own room and the [[cot (furniture)|crib]]. In many parts of the world, bed-sharing simply has the practical benefit of keeping the child warm at night. Bed-sharing has been relatively recently re-introduced into Western culture by practitioners of [[attachment parenting]]. Proponents hold that bed-sharing saves babies' lives (especially in conjunction with [[breastfeeding|nursing]]), <ref name="McKennaSIDS">{{cite journal|year=2005|title=Why babies should never sleep alone: A review of the co-sleeping controversy in relation to SIDS, bed sharing, and breastfeeding|url=http://www.naturalchild.org/james_mckenna/cosleeping.pdf|journal=Paediatric Respiratory Reviews|volume=6|issue=2|pages=134‚Äì152|doi=10.1016/j.prrv.2005.03.006|pmid=15911459|author1=McKenna, J.|author2=T. McDade}}</ref><ref name="McKenna">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M308jA_dDfY&feature=mfu_in_order&list=UL Sleeping with Baby: ABC TV Catalyst, 21 July 2011]</ref> promotes [[human bonding|bonding]], enables the parents to get more [[sleep]] and facilitates breastfeeding. Older babies can breastfeed during the night without waking their mother. Opponents argue that co-sleeping is stressful for the child when they are not co-sleeping.<ref>{{Cite journal|last2=Gozal|first2=D|year=2006|title=Sleep habits and risk factors for sleep-disordered breathing in infants and young toddlers in Louisville, Kentucky|journal=Sleep Medicine|volume=7|issue=3|pages=211‚Äì9|doi=10.1016/j.sleep.2005.11.003|pmid=16564742|author1=Montgomery-Downs|first1=H. E.}}<!-- For controls lacking on evaluators, please do not reuse this.--></ref> They also cite concerns that a parent may [[Asphyxia#Smothering|smother]] the child<ref name="CPSC">[http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PREREL/PRHTML99/99175.html Consumer Product Safety Commission] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060618130458/http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PREREL/PRHTML99/99175.html |date=June 18, 2006 }}</ref> or promote an unhealthy dependence of the child on the parent(s). In addition, they contend that this practice may interfere with the parents' own [[intimate relationship|relationship]], by reducing both [[communication]] and [[sexual intercourse]] at bedtime, and argue that modern-day [[bedding]] is not safe for co-bedding.{{clarify-inline|reason=Above co-bedding is defined as separate from bed-sharing, is that sense intended here?|date=August 2018}}
Because children become accustomed to behaviors learned in early experiences, bed-sharing in infancy will also increase the likelihood of these children to crawl into their parent's bed in ages past infancy.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Invitation to the Life Span, Second Edition|last = Berger|first = Kathleen Stassen|publisher = Worth Publishers|year = 2014|isbn = 1464172056|location = New York|pages = }}</ref>
==Safety and health== Health care professionals disagree about bed-sharing techniques, effectiveness and ethics.<ref name="Mace">Mace, S. Where should babies sleep? Community Pract. 2006 Jun; 79(6):180‚Äì3.</ref> The U.S. [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]]<ref name="CPSC"/> and the [[American Academy of Pediatrics]]<ref name="pediatrics.aappublications.org"/><ref name="Kemp, James S. 2000"/> strongly discourage bed-sharing because of the risk of suffocation or strangulation, but some pediatricians and breast-feeding advocates have opposed this position.<ref>[http://www.medicinenet.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=51747 MedicineNet.com]</ref>
===Advantages=== One study reported mothers getting more sleep and breast-feeding by co-sleeping than other arrangements.<ref>Quillin, S.I. Interaction between feeding method and co-sleeping on maternal-newborn sleep. J Obstet Gynecol Neonatal Nurs. 2004 Sep‚ÄìOct; 33(5):580‚Äì8.</ref> Parents also experience less exhaustion with such ease in feeding and comforting their child by simply reaching over to the child. As a result, co-sleeping also increases the responsiveness of parents to their child's needs.<ref name=":0" />
It has been argued that co-sleeping evolved over five million years, that it alters the infant's sleep experience and the number of maternal inspections of the infant, and that it provides a beginning point for considering possibly unconventional ways of helping reduce the risk of [[sudden infant death syndrome]] (SIDS).<ref name="McKennaSIDS"/><ref name=McKenna/><ref>McKenna, J. Experimental studies of infant-parent co-sleeping: mutual physiological and behavioral influences and their relevance to SIDS (sudden infant death syndrome). Early Hum Dev. 1994 Sep 15; 38(3):187‚Äì201.</ref>
Stress hormones are lower in mothers and babies who co-sleep, specifically the balance of the stress hormone cortisol, the control of which is essential for a baby's healthy growth.<ref>Hofer, M. "The mother-infant interactionas a regulator of infant physiology and behavior", ''Sympiosis in Parent-Offspring Interactions'', New York: Plenum, 1983</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hofer | first1 = M. | title = Some thoughts on the tranduction of experience from a developmental perspective | url = | journal = Psychosomatic Medicine | volume = 44 | issue = 19| page = 1982 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last2=Shair|first2=H.|title=Control of sleep-wake states in the infant rat, by features of the mother-infant relationship|url=|journal=Developmental Psychobiology|volume=15|issue=|pages=229‚Äì243|last1=Hofer|first1=M.|name-list-format=vanc|doi=10.1002/dev.420150307}}</ref> In studies with animals, infants who stayed close to their mothers had higher levels of growth hormones and enzymes necessary for brain and heart growth.<ref>{{cite journal|last2=Suskind|first2=M.|last3=Schanberg|first3=S.|year=1978|title=Maternal behavior as a regulator of polyamine biosynthesis in brain and heart of developing rat pups|url=|journal=Science|volume=199|issue=4327|pages=445‚Äì447|doi=10.1126/science.202031|pmid=202031|last1=Butler|first1=S.R.|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last2=Butler|last3=Schanberg|first3=S.|year=1978|title=Selective depression of serum growth hormone during maternal deprivation in rat pups|url=|journal=Science|volume=201|issue=4360|pages=1035‚Äì1036|doi=10.1126/science.684424|last1=Kuhn|first1=C.M.|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Also, the physiology of co-sleeping babies is more stable, including more stable temperatures, more regular heart rhythms, and fewer long pauses in breathing than babies who sleep alone.<ref>Field, T. ''Touch in early development'', N.J.: Lawrence Erlbaum and Assoc., 1995</ref><ref>Reite, M. and J.P. Capitanio. "On the nature of social separation and social attachment", ''The psychobiology of attachment and separation, New York: Academic Press, 1985, p. 228‚Äì238''</ref>
Besides physical developmental advantages, co-sleeping may also promote long-term emotional health. In long-term follow-up studies of infants who slept with their parents and those who slept alone, the children who co-slept were happier, less anxious, had higher self-esteem, were less likely to be afraid of sleep, had fewer behavioral problems, tended to be more comfortable with intimacy, and were generally more independent as adults.<ref>Crawford, M. "Parenting practices in the Basque Country: Implications of infant and child-hood sleeping location for personality development", ''Ethos'', 1994, 22, 1: 42‚Äì82.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=The cosleeping habits of military children|url=|journal=Military medicine|volume=1992|issue=|pages=196‚Äì200|last1=Forbes|first1=J.F.|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>Heron, P. "Non-reactive cosleeping and child behavior: Getting a good night's sleep all night, every night", ''Master's thesis, Department of Psychology, University of Bristol'', 1994</ref><ref>{{cite journal|year=2004|title=Co-sleeping: Help or hindrance for young children's independence?|journal=Infant and Child Development|volume=13|issue=December|pages=369‚Äì388|doi=10.1002/icd.365|author1=Keller, M.A.|author2=W.A. Goldberg}}</ref>
===Opposing arguments and precautions=== Some parents pose threats to infants due to their behaviors and conditions, such as smoking or drinking heavily, taking drugs, a history of skin infections, obesity, or any other specific risk-increasing traits.<ref name=Mace/><ref name=":1" /> In addition, there are certain dangerous behaviors that increase SIDS and should be avoided whether placing a baby in a crib or co-sleeping: infants should always sleep on their backs on a firm surface (not waterbeds, pillows, recliners, or couches), mattresses should intersect the bedframe tightly, there should be no stuffed animals or soft toys near the baby, blankets should be light, a baby's head should never be covered, and other SIDS risk factors should be avoided.<ref name=":43">[http://cosleeping.nd.edu/safe-co-sleeping-guidelines/ McKenna, James, "Safe Co-Sleeping Guidelines"]</ref>
Co-sleeping deaths in [[Texas]] reached at least 182 in the 2013-2014 fiscal year, which ends on August 31, compared to 169 in the 2012-2013 period. Nearly all of the infants who died were under the age of one year. John Lennan, a spokesman for [[Webb County, Texas|Webb County]] child protective services in [[Laredo, Texas|Laredo]], said that each family's situation is examined individually to offer recommendations for a safe environment for the children. The key to such sleeping arrangements is to make sure that the infant has room to breathe while sleeping, he added.<ref>Cesar G. Rodriguez, "Infant deaths" Co-sleeping tragedies rise, ''[[Laredo Morning Times]]'', August 10, 2014, p. 1</ref>
Co-sleeping also increases the risks of suffocation and strangulation. The soft quality of the mattresses, comforters, and pillows may suffocate the infants.<ref name=":0" /> Some experts, then, recommend that the [[bed (furniture)|bed]] should be firm, and should not be a [[waterbed]] or [[couch]]; and that heavy [[quilt]]s, comforters, and [[pillow]]s should not be used. Another common advice given to prevent suffocation is to keep a baby on its back, not its stomach.<ref name=":1">[http://www.medicinenet.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=51747 MedicineNet.com] [http://iparenting.com/sears/columns/co-sleep.htm IParenting.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060623171312/http://iparenting.com/sears/columns/co-sleep.htm |date=2006-06-23 }}.</ref> Parents who roll over during their sleep could inadvertently crush and/or suffocate their child, especially if they are heavy sleepers, over-tired or over-exhausted and/or obese.<ref name=":1" /> There is also the risk of the baby falling to a hard floor, or getting wedged between the bed and the wall or headboard. A proposed solution to these problems is the bedside bassinet, in which, rather than bed-sharing, the baby's bed is placed next to the parent's bed.<ref name=":0" />
The presence of the child in the parent's bedroom also raises the concern of a lack of privacy between the parents and the child. The lack of privacy may result in increased tension and reduced intimacy between a couple.<ref name=":0" />
Another precaution recommended by experts is that young children should never sleep next to babies under nine months of age.<ref>Sears, William MD et al. ''The Baby Sleep Book'', Brown, Little & Company, 2005, p. 131</ref>
A 2008 report explored the relationship between ad hoc parental behaviors similar to traditional co-sleeping methodology, though the study's subjects typically utilized cribs and other paraphernalia counter to co-sleeping models. While babies who had been exposed to behaviors reminiscent of co-sleeping had significant problems with sleep later in life, the study concluded that the parental behaviors were a reaction to already-present sleep difficulties. Most relationships between parental behavior and sleeping trouble were not statistically significant when controlled for those preexisting conditions. Further, typical co-sleeping parental behavior, like maternal presence at onset of sleep, were found to be protective factors against sleep problems.<ref>Simard, V., et al. (2008). The Predictive Role of Maladaptive Parental Behaviors, Early Sleep Problems, and Child/Mother Psychological Factors. Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine</ref>
===Association with sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)=== Co-sleeping can often be regarded as an unnecessary practice that can be associated with issues such as [[sudden infant death syndrome]] (SIDS).<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Mitchell|first=A|date=2009|title=SIDS: Past, present and future.|url=|journal=Acta Paediatr|volume=98|pages=1712‚Äì9|doi=10.1111/j.1651-2227.2009.01503.x|pmid=19807704|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Alm|first=B|date=2007|title=To co-sleep or not to sleep|url=|journal=Acta Paediatrica|volume=96|pages=1385‚Äì1386|doi=10.1111/j.1651-2227.2007.00524.x|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> However, research shows that opinions vary in the association between SIDS and co-sleeping.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Schluter, Paterson, Percival|date=2007|title=Infant care practices associated with sudden infant death syndrome: Findings from the pacific islands families study|url=|journal=Journal of Paediatrics and Child Health|volume=43|pages=388‚Äì393|doi=10.1111/j.1440-1754.2007.01085.x|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> The most controversial issue regarding SIDS is whether bed sharing is a main cause, and whether it should be avoided or encouraged.<ref name=":2" />
Research indicates that co-sleeping, particularly bed sharing should be avoided as it increases the risk of SIDS.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> Controversially, research shows that if co-sleeping practices are done in an appropriate and safe manner it can be very beneficial and reduce risk of SIDS occurring.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5" /> The Pacific Islands Families study, conducted in New Zealand, showed that the adoption of safe bed-sharing and room-sharing practices were saving infant lives and that there was no infant that died from SIDS.<ref name=":5" />
===Products for infants=== There are several products that can be used to facilitate safe co-sleeping with an infant: * special-purpose bedside [[bassinet]]s, sidecar sleepers and [[bedside sleeper]]s, which attach directly to the side of an adult bed and are open to the parent's side, but have barriers on the other three sides.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2006|title=Co-sleeping, an ancient practice: issues of the past and present, and possibilities for the future|url=|journal=Sleep Med. Rev.|volume=10|issue=6|pages=407‚Äì17|doi=10.1016/j.smrv.2005.12.001|pmid=17112752|last1=Thoman|first1=E.B.}}</ref> * bed top co-sleeping products designed to prevent the baby from rolling off the adult bed and to absorb breastmilk and other nighttime leaks. * side rails to prevent the child from rolling off the adult bed. * co-sleeping infant enclosures which are placed directly in the adult bed. * specially designed separate sleeping bags for parents and infants which prevent covers being inadvertently pulled over the baby's head. * wahakura : A simple woven basket that allows babies to safely sleep in the same bed as parents.<ref>http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/308319/researcher-sure-pepi-pods-save-lives</ref>
==Prevalence== A study of a small population in [[Northeast England]] showed a variety of nighttime parenting strategies and that 65% of the sample had bed-shared, 95% of them having done so with both parents. The study reported that some of the parents found bedsharing effective, yet were covert in their practices, fearing disapproval of health professionals and relatives.<ref>Hooker, F. Sleeping like a baby: attitudes and experiences of bedsharing in northeast England. Med Anthropol. 2001; 19(3):203‚Äì22.</ref> A National Center for Health Statistics survey from 1991 to 1999 found that 25% of American families always, or almost always, slept with their baby in bed, 42% slept with their baby sometimes, and 32% never bed-shared with their baby.<ref>Sears, William MD et al. ''ibid'', p. 107</ref>
===Socioeconomic factors=== Initial assumptions on co-sleeping may place it in a context of income and socioeconomic status. Generally, families of low socioeconomic status will be unable to afford a separate room for a child while those of high socioeconomic status can more easily afford a home with a sufficient number of rooms.<ref name=":0" /> However, statistical data shows the prevalence of co-sleeping in wealthy Japanese families and the ability of poor Western families to still find a separate space for their child, suggests that the acceptance of co-sleeping is a result of culture.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Sleep characteristics of young children in Japan: Internet study and comparison with other Asian countries|last = Kohyama|first = Jun|date = 2011|journal = Pediatrics International|accessdate = |doi = |pmid = |last2 = Mindell|first2 = Jodi|last3 = Sadeh|first3 = Avi}}</ref>
===Cultural factors=== Several studies show that the prevalence of co-sleeping is a result of cultural preference. In a study of 19 nations, a trend emerged, depicting a widely accepted practice of co-sleeping in Asian, African, and Latin American countries, while European and North American countries rarely practiced it.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Cross-cultural differences in infant and toddler sleep|last = Mindell|first = Jodi A.|date = 2010|journal = Sleep Medicine|accessdate = |doi = 10.1016/j.sleep.2009.04.012 |last2 = Sadeh|first2 = Avi |volume=11 |pages=274‚Äì280}}</ref> This trend resulted mostly from the respective fears of parents: Asian, African, and Latin American parents worried about the separation between the parents and the child, while European and North American parents feared a lack of privacy for both the parents and the child.<ref name=":0" />
==See also== * [[Infant bed]] * ''[[Secrets of the Baby Whisperer]]'' (book) * [[Sudden infant death syndrome]] * [[Overlying]]
==References== <references />
===Further reading=== *Moreno MA, Rivara FP. Bed Sharing: A Controversial but Common Practice. [[JAMA Pediatrics]]. 2013;167:1088. *Jackson, Deborah. ''Three in a Bed: The Benefits of Sharing Your Bed with Your Baby,'' New York: [[Bloomsbury Publishing|Bloomsbury]], 1999. * McKenna, James J. ''Sleeping with Your Baby,'' Washington, D.C.: [[Platypus Media]], 2007. * {{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0012-1649.28.4.604 | last1 = Morelli | first1 = G.A. | last2 = Rogoff | first2 = B. | last3 = Oppenheim | first3 = D. | last4 = Goldsmith | first4 = D. | year = 1992 | title = Cultural variation in infant's sleeping arrangements: Questions of Independence | url = |journal = [[Developmental Psychology (journal)|Developmental Psychology]] | volume = 28 | issue = 4| pages = 604‚Äì613 }} * [[Tine Thevenin|Thevenin, Tine]]. ''The Family Bed,'' New Jersey: [[Avery Publishing|Avery Publishing Group]], 1987. * Simard, V., et al. (2008). The Predictive Role of Maladaptive Parental Behaviors, Early Sleep Problems, and Child/Mother Psychological Factors. ''Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine'' Available at: http://archpedi.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/short/162/4/360
{{Parenting|state=collapsed}}

'''Dewitt H. Parker''' (1885‚Äì1949) was a professor of [[philosophy]] at the [[University of Michigan]]. Appointed department chair in 1929,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shaw|first1=Wilfred Byron, ed.|title=The University of Michigan, an Encyclopedic Survey, Vol. II|date=1951|publisher=University of Michigan Press|page=679|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DnIYAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA679&lpg=PA679&dq=DeWitt+Parker%27s+1926+Analysis+of+Art&source=bl&ots=hTOJtEcDQh&sig=jY2layftTZv7livhZovKX-05Jd0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEAQ6AEwB2oVChMIjcb7kI3vxwIVCPaACh3X6gOY#v=onepage&q=DeWitt%20Parker's%201926%20Analysis%20of%20Art&f=false|accessdate=11 September 2015}}</ref> Parker published works on [[metaphysics]], [[aesthetics]], and [[ethics]].
== Publications ==
===Books=== * (1917) ''The Self and Nature'' * (1920) ''The Principles of Aesthetics'' ([http://www.authorama.com/principles-of-aesthetics-1.html available in the public domain]) * (1926) ''The Analysis of Art'' * (1931) ''Human Values'' * (1941) ''Experience and Substance'' * (1957) ''The Philosophy of Value'' (with [[William Frankena]]) <ref>{{cite web|title=The Philosophy of Value - Except|url=https://www.questia.com/library/7130225/the-philosophy-of-value|website=Questia|accessdate=11 September 2015}}</ref>
===Journal articles=== *(1950) ''Is There a Third Kind of Knowledge?'' [[Philosophical Review]] 59 (2):221-229. *(1946) ''Rejoinder to Mr. Lepley'', Philosophical Review 55 (3):288-291. *(1945) ''Esse Est Percipi, with Particular Reference to Number'', [[Journal of Philosophy]] 42 (11):281-291. *(1945) ''Knowledge by Acquaintance'', Philosophical Review 54 (1):1-18. *(1945) ''Knowledge by Description'', Philosophical Review 54 (5):458-488. *(1944) ''Some Comments on "Reformed Materialism and Intrinsic Endurance"'' Philosophical Review 53 (4):383-391. *(1938) ''Value and Existence'' [[Ethics (journal)|Ethics]] 48 (4):475-486. *(1934) ''Reflexive Relations: A Rejoinder.'' Philosophical Review 43 (3):295-300. *(1934) ''The Metaphysics of Value I'' [[International Journal of Ethics]] 44 (3):293-312. *(1933) ''Reflexive Relations'', Philosophical Review 42 (3):303-311. *(1932) ''A Symposium: The Aim and Content of Graduate Training in Ethics'', with [[George P. Adams]], [[C. J. Ducasse]], [[Walter Goodnow Everett]], DeWitt Parker, [[F.C. Sharp]] & [[J.H. Turfs]], International Journal of Ethics 43 (1):53-64. *(1929) ''On the Notion of Value'', Philosophical Review 38 (4):303-325. *(1928) ''[[Alfred Henry Lloyd]], 1864-1927'' with [[Arthur Lyon Cross]] & [[R.M. Wenley]], Journal of Philosophy 25 (5):124-130. *(1910) ''Knowledge and Volition'', [[Journal of Philosophy, Psychology and Scientific Methods]] 7 (22):594-602.
==References== <references />
==External links== *{{Gutenberg author|id=Dewitt_H._Parker|name=Dewitt H. Parker}} *{{Worldcat id|lccn-nr95-8113}} * [http://www.lib.umich.edu/faculty-history/faculty/dewitt-h-parker/memorial University of Michigan Faculty History - Memorial page]
{{aesthetics}}

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Disinformation (book)}} {{good article}} {{Infobox book | italic title = | name = Dezinformatsia | image = Dezinformatsia book.jpg | image_size = 250px | alt = Dezinformatsia | caption = Dezinformatsia | authors = [[Richard H. Shultz]] and [[Roy Godson]] | audio_read_by = | title_orig = Dezinformatsia: Active Measures in Soviet Strategy | orig_lang_code = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = [[Disinformation]] | genre = non-fiction | set_in = | publisher = Pergamon-Brassey's | publisher2 = | pub_date = 1984 | english_pub_date = | published = | media_type = Paperback | pages = 210 | awards = | isbn = 978-0-08-031573-7 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = The Soviet Union and Revolutionary Warfare (1990) | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} '''''Dezinformatsia: Active Measures in Soviet Strategy''''' (and a later edition published as '''''Dezinformatsia: The Strategy of Soviet Disinformation''''') is a non-fiction book about [[disinformation]] and [[information warfare]] used by the [[KGB]] during the [[Soviet Union]] period, as part of their [[active measures]] tactics. The book was co-authored by [[Richard H. Shultz]], professor of international politics at [[Tufts University]], and [[Roy Godson]], professor emeritus of government at [[Georgetown University]]. Shultz and Godson discuss Soviet disinformation tactics including injection of [[Communist propaganda]] through covert groups within the [[U.S.S.R.]] tasked with disrupting activities of the [[North Atlantic Treaty Organization]] and the U.S. The book explains disinformation methods including [[forgery as covert operation]], [[agents of influence]], and using [[social influence]] to turn targets into [[useful idiot]]s. They focus on disinformation activities of Soviet intelligence from 1960 to 1980. Shultz and Godson discuss case studies as examples of Soviet disinformation, including a French journalist covertly financed by Russian agents in order to publish biased material against Western interests, and the [[front organization]] activities of the [[World Peace Council]]. They back up their analyses with two Soviet intelligence [[defection|defectors]]. ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'' called the book a "useful survey" of how Soviet intelligence used disinformation "to further its strategic aims such as discrediting America and weakening NATO". ''The Journal of Conflict Studies'' described it as "a useful introduction to a field of knowledge" of importance to security experts, the [[United States Intelligence Community]], and diplomats. ''[[Society (journal)|Society]]'' called ''Dezinformatsia'', "a highly readable and insightful book". ''[[Political Science Quarterly]]'' gave the work a negative review, criticizing the book's writing style and methodological rigor. == Background == [[File:2017 March 30 Roy Godson.png|thumb|left|upright|Author [[Roy Godson]]]] [[Richard H. Shultz]] received his PhD in [[political science]] from [[Miami University]] in 1976, and during the period 1977‚Äì1978 did post-doctoral work at the [[University of Michigan]].{{cite web | url=http://fletcher.tufts.edu/~/media/Fletcher/Directory/CVs/cv_Shultz_Richard_April_2014.pdf |title=Curriculum Vitae ‚Äì Professor Richard H. Shultz, Jr. | date= | publisher= The Fletcher School | location= | accessdate= Aug 8, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140424102750/http://fletcher.tufts.edu/~/media/Fletcher/Directory/CVs/cv_Shultz_Richard_April_2014.pdf | archivedate=2014-04-24 |deadurl=no}} Shultz became part of [[The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy]], [[Tufts University]] as international politics professor in 1983, and rose to become director of the [[International Security Studies Program (Fletcher School)|International Security Studies Program (ISSP)]].{{cite journal|last1= Pfaltzgraff|first1= Robert L.|last2= Shultz|first2= Richard H.|year= 2013|title= International Security Studies: Looking Back and Moving Ahead|journal= [[The Fletcher Forum of World Affairs]]|volume= 37|issue= 3|pages= 95‚Äì109|doi= |url= http://www.fletcherforum.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Pfaltzgraff-Shultz-FA.pdf|accessdate= Jan 20, 2014|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140221224335/http://www.fletcherforum.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Pfaltzgraff-Shultz-FA.pdf|archivedate= 2014-02-21|df= }} Shultz was the only non-government member of the Special Operations Policy Advisory Group for the [[United States Department of Defense]]. After the publication of ''Dezinformatsia: Active Measures in Soviet Strategy'', Shultz authored another book on Soviet war tactics: ''The Soviet Union and Revolutionary Warfare''.{{citation|first=Richard H.|last=Shultz|authorlink=Richard H. Shultz|title=The Soviet Union and Revolutionary Warfare|year=1990|publisher=The Hoover Institution Press, [[Stanford University]]|isbn=978-0-8179-8712-1}} [[Roy Godson]] graduated with a PhD from [[Colombia University]], with a focus on [[international politics]] and [[national security]].{{citation|title=The CIA and the American Ethic: An Unfinished Debate |page= iv|first=Ernest W. |last=Lefever|year=1979|publisher=Ethics and Public Policy Center, [[Georgetown University]]|isbn=978-0-89633-031-3}} Godson is a [[Georgetown University]] emeritus professor of government.{{citation|first=Giles |last=Scott-Smith |title=Western Anti-Communism and the Interdoc Network: Cold War Internationale|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|page=190|year=2012|series=Palgrave Macmillan Transnational History Series|isbn=978-0-230-22126-0}} Godson testified before the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]] in 2017, to give background on the Senate investigation into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]].{{citation|first=Roy|last=Godson|url=https://www.intelligence.senate.gov/sites/default/files/documents/os-rgodson-033017.pdf|title=Disinformation: A Primer in Russian Active Measures and Influence Campaigns|date=March 30, 2017|work=Written Testimony of Roy Godson to the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, Open Hearing, March 30, 2017|publisher=[[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]], [[United States Senate]]}} He has served as president of the National Strategy Information Center, [[Washington, D.C.]]{{citation|page=114|title=Future Trends and New Approaches in Defeating the Terrorism Threat|year=2013|publisher=IOS Press|isbn=978-1-61499-271-4|first=U|last=G√ºrbuz|series=Nato Science for Peace and Security Series E: Human and Societal Dynamics}} Godson went on to author and edit multiple other books on covert operations and intelligence, including: ''Dirty Tricks or Trump Cards'',{{citation|title=Dirty Tricks or Trump Cards|first=Roy|last=Godson|series=Brassey's Intelligence & National Security Library|publisher=Brassey's|year=1995|isbn=978-0-7658-0699-4}} and ''Comparing Foreign Intelligence''.{{citation|title=Comparing Foreign Intelligence|first=Roy|last=Godson|publisher=Macmillan|year=1988|isbn=978-0-08-034702-8}} == Contents summary == [[File:Disinformation- A Primer in Russian Active Measures and Influence.pdf|thumb|upright|left|Roy Godson's 2017 testimony to the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]], drawing from his book ''Dezinformatsia'']] ''Dezinformatsia'' describes [[disinformation]] tactics used by the intelligence services of the [[Soviet Union]] including the [[KGB]], against foreign enemies including the United States. The authors define disinformation as: "false, incomplete, or misleading information that is passed, fed, or confirmed to a targeted individual, group, or country."{{citation|author1=Garth Jowett |author2=Victoria O'Donnell|title=Propaganda and Persuasion|pages=21‚Äì23|publisher=Sage Publications|isbn=978-1-4129-0898-6|year=2005|chapter=What Is Propaganda, and How Does It Differ From Persuasion?}} The book explains the covert groups within the [[Soviet Union]] tasked with disrupting government activities of the countries belonging to the [[North Atlantic Treaty Organization]], and the U.S., through injection of [[Communist propaganda]]. The authors place the Soviet policy of [[active measures]] within a broader strategy of [[Russian military deception]] in favor of domestic [[national security]]. They focus their discussion on disinformation conducted by the Soviet intelligence between the period of 1960‚Äì1980. Shultz and Godson note that manipulated groups involve both official departments of the Soviet state, as well as [[non-governmental organization]]s which lack independence from the state control itself. Specific goals exported by covert Soviet government channels and groups in the [[Western world]] were financed by Soviet intelligence operations. These covert operations were coordinated so as to have maximum impact related to major international incidents. [[File:Disinformation vs Misinformation.jpg|thumb|300px|Graphic showing differences between disinformation, [[misinformation]] and [[hoax]].
(Wikimedia Foundation presentation)]] As a case study of disinformation, the authors describe journalist {{illm|Pierre-Charles Path√©|lt=Pierre-Charles Path√©|fr|Pierre-Charles Path√©}}, whose publication in France was secretly financed by Soviet intelligence. Its contents were biased against the Western world in favor of the Soviet agenda, and had considerable impact on public opinion. In another example, the authors bring forth an analysis of the [[World Peace Council]], which operated as a [[front organization]] for Soviet intelligence. They discuss its operations negatively impacting both NATO and the U.S. Shultz and Godson back up their analyses with interviews from two Soviet officials who had [[defection|defected]] from their posts in Soviet intelligence, and spoke of disinformation campaigns against Western interests. The authors detail commonly used disinformation tactics by the Soviet intelligence agencies, including [[forgery as covert operation]] in order to fool target dupes into believing such fabricated documents were real. Additionally, the writers explain how Soviet [[secret agent|covert spies]] were able to bring [[agents of influence]] into their fold and do their bidding, whether knowingly or through [[social influence]] as a [[useful idiot]]. Shultz and Godson note that after the Soviet term ''dezinformatsia'' became widely known in the 1980s in the English language as ''disinformation'', native speakers of English broadened the term as "any government communication (either overt or covert) containing intentionally false and misleading material, often combined selectively with true information, which seeks to mislead and [[Psychological manipulation|manipulate]] either elites or a mass audience." == Release and reception == ''Dezinformatsia'' was released in a paperback edition in 1984.{{citation|title=Dezinformatsia: Active Measures in Soviet Strategy|year=1984|first1=Richard H.|last1=Shultz|first2=Roy|last2=Godson|publisher=Pergamon-Brassey's|isbn=978-0-08-031573-7}}{{oclc|299387801}} It was issued again in paperback in 1986 under the same title,{{citation|title=Dezinformatsia: Active Measures in Soviet Strategy|year=1986|first1=Richard H.|last1=Shultz|first2=Roy|last2=Godson|publisher=Berkley|isbn=978-0-425-08772-5}}{{oclc|493594237}} and also with the different title ‚Äî ''Dezinformatsia: The Strategy of Soviet Disinformation''.{{citation|title=Dezinformatsia: The Strategy of Soviet Disinformation|year=1986|first1=Richard H.|last1=Shultz|first2=Roy|last2=Godson|publisher=Berkley Books|isbn=978-0-425-08772-5}} John C. Campbell reviewed the book for the journal ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'', and wrote: "The Shultz/Godson book is a useful survey of how the Soviet Union uses 'disinformation,' propaganda, agents, covert political techniques and front organizations to influence events in foreign countries and to further its strategic aims such as discrediting America and weakening NATO."{{citation|oclc=5546902158|url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/reviews/capsule-review/1984-09-01/dezinformatsia-active-measures-soviet-strategy-new-lies-old|journal=[[Foreign Affairs]]|date=September 1, 1984|first=John C.|last=Campbell|title=Dezinformatsia: Active Measures in Soviet Strategy|volume=63|issue=1|issn=0015-7120}} Campbell criticized the dry nature of some of the facts revealed in the book, "Parts of the presentation are novel, but the revelations are not particularly sensational." Campbell concluded stories in the book should not be taken at face value, "The author's KGB experience and background doubtless give him a special vantage point, but most of this story can be taken with several grains of salt." Writing in ''Conflict Quarterly'' for ''The Journal of Conflict Studies'', David Charters questioned why the book did not present more of an analysis on the aggregate impact of all of the disinformation campaigns, before noting such a task would be difficult to assess.{{citation|first=David|last=Charters|volume=5|issue=4|year=1985|title=Richard H. Shultz and Roy Godson, Dezinformatsia: Active Measures in Soviet Strategy|journal=Conflict Quarterly|page=79|url=https://journals.lib.unb.ca/index.php/JCS/article/view/14695/15764|oclc=5127078304}} The reviewer asked why the book did not fully address questions including, "Did any of the forgeries described have a significant political impact on the intended target, and on U.S. relations with the country concerned, or were they merely of nuisance value?" ''Conflict Quarterly'' criticized such absence in the book and identified it as an academic deficiency, writing, "Without answers to questions such as these, it is difficult to accept, at face value, the authors' conclusions." Charters concluded the book was "a useful introduction to a field of knowledge which ... is likely to continue to expand in importance for diplomats, the intelligence community, and scholars of international security affairs. Stephen Sloan reviewed the book for the journal ''[[Society (journal)|Society]]'', writing: "Richard H. Shultz and Roy Godson are to be credited for writing a highly readable and insightful book that can enable policy-makers, academics, and concerned members of the public to understand a form of political warfare that until recently was only rarely recognized in the West."{{citation|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/book-reviews/10867920/dezinformatsia-active-measures-soviet-strategy-book|journal=[[Society (journal)|Society]]|title=Dezinformatsia: Active Measures in Soviet Strategy|last=Sloan|first=Stephen|date=January 1985|volume=22|issue=2|page=84}} He called the work "ground breaking research". Sloan concluded, "Shultz and Godson have provided an awareness of a threat that should be acted upon." ''[[Political Science Quarterly]]'' gave a more critical assessment of the book, with reviewer Ellen Mickiewicz commenting, "In the second chapter, the discussion of the organization of Soviet foreign propaganda activities is so fuzzy as to be confusing."{{citation|title=Review ‚Äì Reviewed Work(s): Dezinfomatsia: Active Measures in Soviet Strategy. by Richard H. Shultz and Roy Godson|first=Ellen|last= Mickiewicz|journal=[[Political Science Quarterly]]|volume=99|issue=4|date=1984|pages=770‚Äì771|jstor=2150750|doi=10.2307/2150750}} She criticized the rigor of the book's research methodology. Mickiewicz concluded, "This book is not the successor to Frederic Barghoorn's ''Soviet Foreign Propaganda'' (1964); the topic is timely and interesting, but it requires a more considered and informed analysis." == See also == {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Active measures]] * [[Active Measures Working Group]] * [[Counter Misinformation Team]] * [[Denial and deception]] * [[False flag]] * [[Fear, uncertainty and doubt]] * [[Forgery as covert operation]] * [[Information warfare]] * [[Internet manipulation]] * [[Media censorship and disinformation during the Gezi Park protests]] * [[Manufacturing Consent]] * [[Operation Toucan (KGB)]] * ''[[The Plot to Hack America]]'' * [[Politico-media complex]] * [[Post-truth politics]] * [[Propaganda in the Soviet Union]] * [[Russian military deception]] * [[Social engineering (political science)]] * [[Persuasion]] {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == ;Additional book reviews * {{citation|title=Book reviews|author=Roger W. {{unreferenced|date=September 2009}} '''Emilio Betti''' ([[Camerino]], 20 August 1890 ‚Äì [[Camorciano di Camerino]], 11 August 1968) was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[jurist]], [[Roman Law]] scholar, [[philosopher]] and [[theologian]]. He is best known for his contributions to [[hermeneutics]], part of a broad interest in interpretation. As a legal theorist, Betti is close to [[Interpretivism (legal)|interpretivism]].
Betti's intellectual support of [[fascism]] between the end of [[World War I]] and the beginning of the 1920s led him to be arrested in 1944, in Camerino. Betti remained in prison for about a month, as decided by the [[Comitato di Liberazione Nazionale]]. In August 1945, Betti was presented to court and absolved of every accusation.
His political choices, anyway, have not diminished the value and importance of his work. Between many other things, Betti was one of the members of the drafting commission for the Italian [[civil code]] of 1942.
Betti is perhaps best known for his work in [[hermeneutics]]. He took issue with the hermeneutic views of [[Hans Georg Gadamer]] and argued that interpreters should attempt to reconstruct the author's intentions. His work influenced the work of [[E. D. Hirsch]], the chief English-language spokesman for authorial intention. However, his influence in English has been limited by the lack of translations of his hermeneutic work.
==Major works==
Betti was a prolific writer. This is just a small part of his works:
*''Sulla opposizione dell'exceptio sull'actio e sulla concorrenza tra loro'' (1913). *''La vendicatio romana primitiva e il suo svolgimento storico nel diritto privato e nel processo'' (1915). *''L'antitesi storica tra iudicare (pronuntiatio) e damnare (condemnatio) nello svolgimento del processo romano'' (1915). *''Studii sulla litis aestimatio del processo civile romano'': I Pavia (1915), III (Camerino, 1919). *''Sul valore dogmatico della categoria contahere in giuristi proculiani e sabiniani'' (1916). *''La restaurazione sullana e il suo esito (Contributo allo studio della crisi della costituzione repubblicana in Roma)'' (1916). *''La struttura dell'obbligazione romana e il problema della sua genesi'' (1919). *''Il concetto della obbligazione costruito dal punto di vista dell'azione'' (1920). *''Trattato dei limiti soggettivi della cosa giudicata in diritto romano'' (1922). *''La tradizione nel diritto romano classico e giustinianeo'' (1924‚Äì25). *''Esercitazioni romanistiche su casi pratici: I, anormalit√† del negozio giuridico'' (1930). *''Diritto romano: parte generale'' (1935). *''Teoria generale del negozio giuridico'' (1943). *''Teoria generale delle obbligazioni'' (1953‚Äì1955). *''Teoria generale della interpretazione'' (1955‚Äì1960). *''Teoria delle obbligazioni in diritto romano'' (1956). *''Teoria generale della interpretazione'' (1955‚Äì1960). *''Attualit√† di una teoria generale dell'interpretazione'' (1967).
==References and further reading== * Ciocchetti, Mario (1998). ''Emilio Betti, Giureconsulto e umanista''. Belforte del Chienti.

The '''faculties of the soul''' are the individual characteristics of a [[soul]]. There have been different attempts to define them over the centuries.
==Plato, Aristotle and their followers==
[[Plato]] defined the faculties of the soul in terms of a three-fold division: the intellect (''no√ªs''), the nobler affections (''thum√≥s''), and the appetites or passions (''epithumetik√≥n'')<ref>{{CathEncy|wstitle=Faculties of the Soul}}</ref> [[Aristotle]] also made a three-fold division of natural faculties, into vegetative, appetitive and rational elements,<ref>Aristotle, ''Ethics'' (1976) p. 88-90</ref> though he later distinguished further divisions in the rational faculty, such as the faculty of judgement and that of cleverness (deinotes).<ref>Aristotle, p. 218-222</ref>
Islamic philosophers continued his three-fold division;<ref>S. S. Hawi, ''Islamic Naturalism and Mysticism'' (1974) p. 151</ref> but later Scholastic philosophers defined five groups of faculties:<ref>[[s:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/Faculties of the Soul|Faculties of the Soul]]</ref>
* dun√°meis - the "vegetative" faculty (threptik√≥n), concerned with the maintenance and development of organic life * the appetite (oretik√≥n), or the tendency to any good * the faculty of sense perception (aisthetik√≥n) * the "locomotive" faculty (kinetik√≥n), which presides over the various bodily movements * reason (dianoetik√≥n)
==Calvin== [[John Calvin]] opposed the scholastic philosophers, favoring a two-fold division of the soul, consisting of intellect and of will.<ref>John Calvin, ''Institutes of the Christian Religion'' (2008) p. 104</ref>
==Faculty psychology== The secularisation of the [[Age of Enlightenment]] produced a [[faculty psychology]] of different but inherent mental powers such as intelligence or memory, distinct (as in Aristotelianism) from the acquired habits.<ref>R. Gregory, ''The Oxford Companion to the Mind'' (1987) p. 253-4</ref>
==See also== *[['Aql]] (rational faculty in Islamic philosophy) *[[Jerry Fodor]] *[[Phrenology]] *[[Psychology]] *[[Rational animal]] *[[Thomism]] *[[Trichotomy (philosophy)|Trichotomy]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox philosopher | region = [[Western philosophy]] | era = [[20th-century philosophy]] | image = | caption = | name = Henry Habberley Price | birth_date = 17 May 1899 | birth_place = [[Neath]], [[Glamorganshire]], Wales | death_date = {{d-da|26 November 1984|17 May 1899}} | death_place = [[Oxford]] | alma_mater = [[New College, Oxford]] | school_tradition = [[Analytic philosophy|Analytic]]
[[Nominalism]][https://ndpr.nd.edu/news/resemblance-nominalism-a-solution-to-the-problem-of-universals/ "Review of Gonzalo Rodriguez-Pereyra, ''Resemblance Nominalism: A Solution to the Problem of Universals''" ‚Äì ndpr.nd.edu] | main_interests = [[Philosophy of perception]] | influences = [[H. A. Pritchard]] | influenced = | notable_ideas = Theory of [[afterlife]] }} '''Henry Habberley Price''', FBA (17 May 1899 ‚Äì 26 November 1984), usually cited as '''H. H. Price''', was a [[Welsh people|Welsh]] philosopher, known for his work on the [[philosophy of perception]]. He also wrote on [[parapsychology]]. ==Biography== Born in [[Neath]], [[Glamorganshire]], [[Wales]], Price was educated at [[Winchester College]] and [[New College, Oxford]]. He obtained first-class honours in [[Literae Humaniores]] in 1921. He was a Fellow of Magdalen College, Oxford, 1922‚Äì4, Assistant Lecturer in philosophy at the university of Liverpool (1922‚Äì23), Fellow and Tutor of Trinity College Oxford (1924‚Äì35), Lecturer in philosophy at Oxford (1932‚Äì35) and [[Wykeham Professor of Logic]] and Fellow of New College (1935‚Äì59). Price was president of the [[Aristotelian Society]] from 1943 to 1944. He was elected to the British Academy in 1943. Price is perhaps best known for his work on the [[philosophy of perception]]. He argues for a sophisticated sense-datum account, although he rejects [[phenomenalism]]. In his book ''Thinking and Experience'', he moves from perception to thought and argues for a dispositionalist account of conceptual cognition. Concepts are held to be a kind of intellectual capacity, manifested in perceptual contexts as recognitional capacities. For Price, concepts are not some kind of mental entity or representation. The ultimate appeal is to a species of memory distinct from event recollection. He died in [[Oxford]]. ==Parapsychology== Price had written various publications on [[parapsychology]], often advocating new concepts and theories. He was President of the [[Society for Psychical Research]] (1939‚Äì40, 1960‚Äì1) ===Afterlife=== Price had speculated on the nature of the [[afterlife]] and developed his own hypothesis about what the afterlife may be like. According to Price after death the self will find itself in a dream world of [[memories]] and mental images from their life. Price wrote that the hypothetical "next world would be realms of real mental images." Price however believed that the self may be able to draw upon its memories of previous physical existence to create an environment of totally new images. According to Price, the dream world will not follow the laws of [[physics]] just as ordinary [[dreams]] do not. In addition, he wrote that each person will experience a world of their own, though he also wrote that the dream world doesn't necessarily have to be [[solipsistic]] as different selves may be able to communicate with each other by [[dream telepathy]].Price, H. H., 1953. "Survival and the Idea of ' Another World'," Proceedings of the Society for Psychical Research, 50 (182): 1‚Äì25. Reprinted in John Hick (ed.), 1970. Classical and Contemporary Readings in the Philosophy of Religion, second edition, Englewood Cliffs: Prentice-Hall, pp. 370‚Äì93. Page references to Hick 1970.Price, Hick, and Disembodied Existence, Bruce R. Reichenbach, Religious Studies, Vol. 15, No. 3 (Sep. 1979), pp. 317‚Äì325Toynvee, A., Mant, A.K., Smart, N., Hinton, J., Yudkin, S., Rhode, E., Heywood R., Price, H.H. (1968). Man‚Äôs Concern with Death. London, Great Britain: Hoddler and Stouhton.Christopher Moreman ''Beyond the Threshold: Afterlife Beliefs and Experiences in World Religions'' 2010, p. 270 ===Place memories=== Price had invented the concept of "place memories" (see [[Stone Tape]]). He proposed that [[hauntings]] could be explained by [[memories]] becoming lost from an individual's [[mind]] and then somehow attaching itself to the environment which could be picked up by others as [[hallucinations]].Price, H. H. (1940). Some philosophical questions about telepathy and clairvoyance. Philosophy, 15, 363‚Äì374.[http://www.pamelaheath.com/PDF/PlaceMemory2.pdf Pamela Rae Heath A New Theory on Place Memory] He also believed that "place memories" could explain [[psychometry (paranormal)|psychometry]].James Houran ''From Shaman to scientist: essays on humanity's search for spirits'' 2004, p. 172 ===Psychic ether=== Linking his afterlife hypothesis with the concept of place memories Price proposed another hypothesis called the "psychic ether" hypothesis. He wrote that this hypothesis would explain where the [[memories]] would be stored for [[hauntings]] as well as for [[clairvoyance]], [[ghosts]] and other [[paranormal]] phenomena. Price proposed that a universal psychic ether coexisting [[dimension]] exists as an intermediary between the [[mind|mental]] and ordinary [[matter]]. According to Price the psychic ether consists of images and ideas. Price wrote that apparitions are actually memories from people and that under the right conditions they can be seen as hallucinations. Price believed that the dreamlike world of the afterlife exists in the psychic ether.Price, H. H. (1939). Haunting and the psychic ether hypothesis; with some preliminary reflections on the present condition and possible future of psychical research. Proceedings of the Society for Psychical Research, 45, 307‚Äì343.K. Ramakrishna Rao, V. Gowri Rammohan ''New frontiers of human science: a festschrift for K. Ramakrishna Rao'' 2002, p. 54Dr. Mehra Shrikhande ''Paranormal Experiences'' 2009, p. 90Carroll B. Nash ''Parapsychology, the science of psiology'' 1986, p. 134 According to (Ellwood, 2001) the psychic ether of Price is "a posited level of reality consisting of persisting, dynamic images created by the mind and capable of being perceived by certain persons."Gracia Fay Ellwood ''The uttermost deep: the challenge of near-death experiences'' 2001, p. 268 ===Reception=== Some researchers have attempted to update the afterlife hypothesis of Price. Michael Grosso (1979) in an extension of Price's theory suggested that the "ego may become fragmented in the afterlife state and when ones wish's and desires are played out may experience a transpersonal state akin to those experienced by the mystics".Grosso, M. (1979). The survival of personality in a mind-dependent world. Journal of the American Society for Psychical Research, 73, 367‚Äì380.K. Ramakrishna Rao, V. Gowri Rammohan ''New Frontiers of Human Science: A Festschrift for K. Ramakrishna Rao'' 2002, p. 54 The [[psychical researcher]] Ralph Noyes (1998) published an article discussing the theories of Price and attempted to update them with recent finds in parapsychology. Noyes proposed that the mental world of Price is a "[[psychosphere]]" which he defined as a "vast and complex cauldron of ideas, memories, volitions, desires and all the other furniture of conscious experience and unconscious mental functioning".Ralph Noyes ''The concept of a psychosphere: A heuristic suggestion'' Journal of the Society for Psychical Research (1998) Volume: 62, Issue: 851, Apr 1998, pp. 353‚Äì360 The most common criticism of HH Price's afterlife hypothesis has come from the religious community as his suggestions are not consistent with traditional Christian teaching, nor the teachings of any other [[monotheistic]] religion.Libby Ahluwalia ''Understanding philosophy of religion Edexcel'' 2008, p. 275 == Quotes == "When I see a tomato there is much that I can doubt. I can doubt whether it is a tomato that I am seeing, and not a cleverly painted piece of wax. I can doubt whether there is any material thing there at all. Perhaps what I took for a tomato was really a reflection; perhaps I am even the victim of some hallucination. One thing however I cannot doubt: that there exists a red patch of a round and somewhat bulgy shape, standing out from a background of other colour-patches, and having a certain visual depth, and that this whole field of colour is directly present to my consciousness." *Price, H. H. ''Perception''. London: Methuen & Co. Ltd, 1932. ==Works== *''Perception'' (1932) *''Truth and Corrigibility'' (1936) *''Hume's Theory of the External World'' (1940) *''Thinking and Representation''.(1946) Hertz Trust Philosophical lecture, British Academy *''Thinking and Experience'' (1953; second edition, 1969) *''Belief'' (1969) (1959‚Äì61 [[Gifford Lectures]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20080621234339/http://www.giffordlectures.org/Browse.asp?PubID=TPBELI&Cover=TRUE online]) *''Essays in the Philosophy of Religion'', based on the [[Sarum lectures]] 1971 (1972) *''Philosophical Interactions with Parapsychology: The Major Writings of H. H. Price on Parapsychology and Survival'' (1995) editor [[Frank B. Dilley]] *Collected Works of Henry H. [[File:Rock crusher gears.jpg|thumb|Hard determinists believe people are like highly complex clocks, in that they are both molecular machines]] '''Hard determinism''' (or '''metaphysical determinism''') is a view on [[free will]] which holds that [[determinism]] is true, and that it is [[incompatibilism|incompatible with free will]], and, therefore, that free will does not exist. Although hard determinism generally refers to [[nomological determinism]],<ref name=stanfordincompatibilismarguments>{{cite encyclopedia|last=Vihvelin |first=Kadri |editor=Edward N. Zalta | title=Arguments for Incompatibilism | encyclopedia=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy| edition=Spring 2011 | year=2011 | url=http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2011/entries/incompatibilism-arguments}}</ref> it can also be a position taken with respect to other forms of determinism that necessitate the future in its entirety.<ref name=VanArragon2010>{{cite book|author=Raymond J. VanArragon|title=Key Terms in Philosophy of Religion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JyTohO1AMzwC|accessdate=22 December 2012|date=21 October 2010|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4411-3867-5|page=21}}</ref> Hard determinism is contrasted with [[soft determinism]], which is a [[compatibilist]] form of determinism, holding that free will may exist despite determinism.<ref>[http://www.philosophy-dictionary.org/Hard_determinism Philosophy-Dictionary.org on "Hard Determinism"]</ref> It is also contrasted with [[libertarianism (metaphysics)|metaphysical libertarianism]], the other major form of incompatibilism which holds that free will exists and determinism is false.
== In history == In [[ancient Greece]], [[Socrates]] initiated the rationalistic teaching that any agent is obliged to pursue the chief good conceived by his or her mind.<ref>Plato, Protagoras, 345e; 358c.</ref> The peripatetic naturalist [[Strato of Lampsacus]] speculated that an unconscious divine power acts in the world and causes the origin, growth and breakdown of things.<ref>Cicero, ‚Äò‚ÄôDe natura deorum‚Äô ‚Äò[On the Nature of Gods], I, 35 (XIII).</ref> [[Diodorus Cronus]] asserted the identity of the possible and the necessary and inferred that future events are as determined as the past ones.<ref>Epictetus, ‚Äò ‚ÄòDiscourses‚Äô ‚Äò, B, 19, 1 in ‚Äò ‚ÄòDiscourses, Fragments, Handbook‚Äô ‚Äò, trans. Robin Hard. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014. {{ISBN|0199595186}}.</ref> Chrysippus refuted the "idle argument" invented to discredit determinism as if human efforts were futile in a preordained world; he explained that fated events occur with the engagement of conscious agents.<ref>Origen, ‚Äò ‚Äò Contra Celsum‚Äô ‚Äò, trans. Henry Chadwick. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1965. II, 20, 340.55-342.61.</ref> In the 17th century, both [[John Locke|Locke]]<ref>Locke, John.‚Äô ‚ÄòEssay Concerning Human Understanding‚Äô ‚Äò, XXI.</ref> and [[Spinoza]]<ref>Spinoza, Baruch. ‚Äò ‚ÄòEthica ordine geometrico demonstrata‚Äô ‚Äô [Ethics, Demonstrated in Geometrical Order], Pars II, Propositio XXXV, Scholium; Propositio XLVIII.</ref> argued for strict causality of volitional acts. In the age of enlightenment, [[Baron d‚ÄôHolbach]]<ref>Baron d‚ÄôHolbach, Paul-Henri Thiry. ‚Äò ‚ÄòThe Illusion of Free Will‚Äô ‚Äò in ‚Äò ‚ÄòSystem of Nature‚Äô ‚Äò.</ref> promulgated the naturalistic interpretation of mental events. [[Schopenhauer]] observed that everyone regards himself free ''[[A priori and a posteriori|a priori]]''; however, ''[[A priori and a posteriori|a posteriori]]'' he must discover that he had been obliged to make the decisions he actually made.<ref>Schopenhauer, Arthur. ‚Äò ‚ÄòDie Welt als Wille und Vorstellung‚Äô ‚Äò[The World as Will and Idea]. I Band. Leipzig: Philipp Reclam jr., [s.a.], S.167.</ref> Nietzsche noticed that free decisions are graded as ''[[causa sui]]'', emerging from non-existence.<ref>Nietzsche, Friedrich. ‚Äò ‚ÄòJenseits von Gut und B√∂se‚Äô ‚Äò[Beyond Good and Evil]. Leipzig: C.G.Neumann, 1886, S.21.</ref> Recently [[Daniel Wegner]] stressed the limitations of free will on grounds of experimental evidence for unconscious choice and action.<ref>Wegner, Daniel. ‚Äò ‚ÄòThe mind's best trick: how we experience conscious will‚Äô ‚Äô in ‚Äò ‚ÄòTrends in Cognitive Sciences‚Äô ‚Äò(2003), Vo;ume 7, no.2, p. 65-69.</ref> To prove determinism, the following putative experiment was proposed: all principal differences between the features of an artificial [[zygote]] and that developing naturally can be avoided.<ref>Mele A.R. ‚Äò‚ÄôFree Will and Luck‚Äô ‚Äò. Oxford, New York: Oxford University Press, 2006, p.189, {{ISBN|978-0-19-537439-1}}.</ref>
==Overview== Meeting a challenge, agents make decisions in conformity to the inherited character, life history and current stimuli. The field of acute attention is limited, and motives partly remain unconscious. From the first person's perspective we have an intuitive commitment that many options are available. However, if the total of the mental content is considered from the third person's perspective, only a single decision deemed by the agent as the most favorable at the moment turns out real. The validity of causation for any mental event becomes apparent taking into account their neurophysiological correlates.<ref>Honderich, Ted. ''Mind and Brain: A Theory of Determinism''. Volume 1, Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1990, p.244. {{ISBN|978-0198242826}}.</ref> Different causal descriptions correspond to the mental and physical domain.<ref>Searle J. "Mental causation, conscious and unconscious", ''Int J.Philosophical Studies'' (2000), Volume 8, p.171-177.</ref> Laws of thermodynamics and quantum mechanics govern the latter. Admitting downright mental causation of physiological impulses would mean surplus determination. The surmise that under identical conditions, alternative decisions and actions are possible is disproved by naturalists as an illusion.<ref>Walter H. "Neurophilosophy of free will" in ''Oxford Handbook of Free Will'', Oxford: Oxford University Press [2002], p.565-575.</ref> Hard determinism is not taken to refer merely to a determinism on earth, but in all of reality (e.g. involving the effects of light from other galaxies, etc.); not just during a certain deterministic period of time, but for all time. This also means that the relation of necessity will be bi-directional. Just as the initial conditions of the universe presumably determine all future states, so too does the present necessitate the past. In other words, one could not change any one fact without affecting the entire timeline. Because hard determinists often support this [[Eternalism (philosophy of time)|eternalist]] view of time, they do not believe that there are genuine chances or possibilities, only the idea that events are 100% likely.<ref name=SEPDeterminism>[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/determinism-causal/ Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy,"Causal Determinism"]</ref>
Unlike "law fundamentalists", some philosophers are "law pluralists": they question what it means to have a law of physics. One example is the "Best Standards Analysis", which says that the laws are only useful ways to summarize all past events, rather than there being metaphysically "pushy" entities (this route still brings one into conflict with the idea of free will).{{citation needed|date=February 2012}} Some law pluralists further believe there are simply no laws of physics.<ref name=SEPDeterminism/> The [[mathematical universe hypothesis]] suggests that there are other universes in which the laws of physics and [[fundamental constants]] are different. Andreas Albrecht of [[Imperial College]] in London called it a "provocative" solution to one of the central problems facing physics. Although he "wouldn't dare" go so far as to say he believes it, he noted that "it's actually quite difficult to construct a theory where everything we see is all there is".<ref>{{cite journal |last=Chown |first=Markus |date=June 1998 |title=Anything goes |journal=New Scientist |volume=158 |number=2157 |url=http://space.mit.edu/home/tegmark/toe_press.html}}</ref>
The feasibility of testing determinism is always challenged by what we know, or think we can know, about the idea of a final, all encompassing, [[theory of everything]]. Some physicists challenge the likelihood of determinism on the grounds that certain [[interpretations of quantum mechanics]] stipulate that the universe is fundamentally [[indeterminism|indeterministic]], such as the [[Copenhagen interpretation]]; whereas other interpretations are deterministic, for example, the [[De Broglie-Bohm Theory]] and the [[many-worlds interpretation]]. [[Chaos theory]] describes how a deterministic system can exhibit perplexing behavior that is difficult to predict: as in the [[butterfly effect]], minor variations between the starting conditions of two systems can result in major differences. Yet chaos theory is a wholly deterministic thesis; it merely demonstrates the potential for vastly different consequences from very similar initial conditions. Properly understood, then, it enlightens and reinforces the deterministic claim.<ref name=SEPDeterminism/>
== Implications for ethics == {{see also|Moral responsibility}} [[File:Actroid-DER 01.jpg|thumb|right|140px|Some hard determinists would hold [[Artificial intelligence|robotic beings]] of sufficient intelligence morally responsible (pictured above: attempts to build lifelike machines).]] Hard determinists reject free will. Critics often suggest that, in so doing, the hard determinist also rejects [[ethics]]. The key to this argument rests on the idea that holding a person morally responsible requires for them to make a choice between two, or more, truly possible alternatives. If choice is indeed impossible, then it would be incorrect to hold anyone morally responsible for his or her actions. If this argument holds, hard determinists are restricted to [[moral nihilism]]. This feature, however, is tenable only as far as hard determinists discard responsibility. In a necessitarian world, recourse to merit and blameworthiness is toned down but adherence to ethical and legal values is not ruined. Persons may be appreciated as carriers, executers and defenders of morality. Alternative choice being absent, regret for past misdeeds becomes unreasonable. Nevertheless, one can admonish oneself for one's lapses and resolve to avoid similar behavior in the future.<ref>Pereboom, Derk, ' 'Meaning in life without free will ‚Äò‚Äò, in ''Oxford Handbook of Free Will'', Oxford:Oxford University Press [2002], p.477-488.</ref> Those hard determinists who defend [[ethical realism]] would object to the premise that contra-causal free will is necessary for ethics. Those who are also [[ethical naturalism|ethically naturalistic]] may also point out that there are good reasons to [[punish]] criminals: it is a chance to [[behaviour modification|modify their behaviour]], or their punishment can act as a deterrent for others who would otherwise act in the same manner. The hard determinist could even argue that this understanding of the [[Truth|true]] and [[fallacy of the single cause|various causes]] of a psychopath's behaviour, for instance, allow them to respond even more reasonably or compassionately.<ref>[http://www.samharris.org/blog/item/life-without-free-will Sam Harris, "Life Without Free Will"]</ref>
Hard determinists acknowledge that humans do, in some sense, "choose", or deliberate ‚Äì although in a way that obeys natural laws. For example, a hard determinist might see humans as a sort of [[artificial intelligence|thinking machines]], but believe it is inaccurate to say they "came to a decision" or "chose". Generalization of event causation should circumvent overstatement of external impulses. [[Autotelic]] personalities show a high rate of activities all by themselves. The capacity to resist psychological assault is an impressive evidence of autarkic resources. Determinists even admit that with corresponding knowledge, changes in the genetic depository and consequently behavior are possible.
Up to now, the concepts and terminology of legal affairs follow the pre-reflexive belief in alternative possibilities. As scientific insight advances, the juridical attitude becomes increasingly "external": there should be fewer emotions about offender's will and more concern about the effects of offenses on society. The retributive function of punishment should be rejected as irrational and unjustified. "Lex talionis" is discarded already because of deficient correlation between crime and penalty. If the inveterate notion of "mens rea" is used at all, then only to distinguish intentional actions from inadvertent ones and not to designate an autonomous undertaking of the lawbreaker. At the same time, it is justified to require the perpetrator to critically reconsider his intentions and character, to demand apology and compensation in victims' favor. The rehabilitation service should be used to train the risky circle for keeping the norms of social life.<ref>Caruso Gregg D. ‚Äò ‚ÄòFree will skepticism and criminal behavior: A public health-quarantine model‚Äô ‚Äò.‚Äô ‚ÄòSouthwest Philosophy Review‚Äô ‚Äò(2016), Volume 32, no.1.</ref>
== Psychological effects of belief in hard determinism == Some behavioral anomalies have been observed in persons cultivating the habit of causal awareness. Increased aggressiveness, excessive compliance and reduced helpfulness are reported. Critical assessment of one's own former conduct appeared abated.<ref>Baumeister R.F., Masicampo C.J., De Wall C.N.‚Äô ‚ÄòProsocial benefits of feeling free: disbelief in will increases aggression and reduces helpfulness‚Äô, ‚ÄòPersonality and Social Psychology Bulletin‚Äô (2009), Volume 35, no.2, p.260-268.</ref>
[[William James]] was an [[United States|American]] [[pragmatism|pragmatist]] philosopher who coined the terms "soft determinist" and "hard determinist" in an influential essay titled "The Dilemma of Determinism".<ref>[http://csunx2.bsc.edu/bmyers/WJ1.htmWilliam James - ''The Dilemma of Determinism'']</ref> He argued against determinism, holding that the important issue is not personal responsibility, but hope. He believed that thorough-going determinism leads either to a bleak [[pessimism]] or to a degenerate [[subjectivism]] in moral judgment. He proposed the way to escape the dilemma is to allow a role for [[Randomness|chance]]. James was careful to explain that he would rather "debate about objects than words", however. He did not insist in saying that replacing determinism with a model including chance had to mean we had "free will".
The determinist would counter-argue that there is still reason for hope. Whether or not the universe is determined does not change the fact that the future is unknown, and might very well always be. From a [[Naturalism (philosophy)|naturalist]] point of view, a person's actions still play a role in the shape of that future. Thomas W. Clark, founder and director of the Center for Naturalism, explains that humans are not merely the playthings of patterned, natural forces in the universe - but rather we are ourselves examples of those forces.<ref>[http://www.naturalism.org/freewill1.htm Naturalism.org, "Free Will and Naturalism: A Reply to Corliss Lamont"]</ref> The deterministic view aligns our representations with the faculties and possibilities we actually possess but it should avoid misleading introspection. Admitting agents‚Äô dependence on a drastic background can enhance insight, moderate severity and spare unproductive suffering.<ref>Mazlovskis Arnis.‚Äô ‚ÄôOn free will and determinism‚Äô ‚Äò.‚Äô ‚ÄòReliƒüiski-filozofiski raksti‚Äô ‚Äò[Religious-Philosophical Articles] (2015), XIX, p.22-42. ISSN 1407-1908.</ref> In so far as the mind comprehends universal necessity, the power of emotions is diminished.<ref>The Project Gutenberg E Book: Benedict de Spinoza "The Ethics". Translated from the Latin by R.H.M.Elwes. Posting Date: May 28, 2009. Part V, Proposition VI.</ref>
==See also== * [[Laplace's demon]] * [[Superdeterminism]] * [[Semicompatibilism]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} [[File:Bonn Durchbruch.jpg|thumb|‚ÄûDurchbruch‚Äú ‚Äì [[Plastic arts|plastic]] by Hermann Gl√∂ckner in front of the Bundeshaus [[Bonn]]]] [[File:Gl√∂ckner-Faltung-DD.jpg|thumb|‚ÄûMast mit zwei Faltungszonen‚Äú ‚Äì plastic by Hermann Gl√∂ckner, [[Technische Universit√§t Dresden]]]]
'''Hermann Gl√∂ckner''' (21 January 1889 ‚Äì 25 May 1987) was a German painter and sculptor. He was an important representative of [[Constructivism (art)|constructivism]].
Gl√∂ckner was born in Cotta near [[Dresden]]. He attended the vocational school in [[Leipzig]] in 1903 and worked as a designer for textiles. From 1904 to 1911 he attended the evening classes at the [[Kunstgewerbeschule]] in Dresden, where he became friends with [[Friedrich Kurt Fiedler|Kurt Fiedler]].<ref>Hermann Gl√∂ckner ‚Äì Ein Patriarch der Moderne. Ed. by [[John Erpenbeck]]. Der Morgen. Berlin 1983</ref> Among their lectures were [[Oskar Seyffert]] and [[Carl Rade]], who later was a renowned professor at the [[Dresden Academy of Fine Arts]] and remained a friend of Gl√∂ckner for many years. Gl√∂ckner was mainly interested in [[drawings]], but also in projections and geometry. From 1914 to 1918 he served in [[infantry]] divisions in France, Russia, and Poland.
After [[World War I]] Gl√∂ckner earned some money with the copying of paintings for the [[Gem√§ldegalerie Alte Meister]]. At the Dresden Academy of Fine Arts he studied with [[Otto Gussmann]] from 1923 to 1924.<ref>Die gro√üen Dresdner. 26 Ann√§herungen. Ed. by Karin Nitzschke. Insel Verlag. Frankfurt am Main und Leipzig 1999</ref> [[Hans Grundig]] was among his fellow students. His experimental style, however, did not find everyone's appreciation and Gl√∂ckner left the academy again.<ref>G√ºnter Meissner: Allgemeines K√ºnstlerlexikon: die bildenden K√ºnstler aller Zeiten und V√∂lker. K.G. Saur Verlag 1992. pp 198‚Äì201</ref> As a freelancer he turned to constructivism ever deeper during the following years. In 1932 he became a member of the re-founded ''Dresdner Sezession''. The [[Nazi]]s refused him any opportunities to exhibit and sell his paintings and graphics. So he turned to [[sgraffito]] to earn his living.
Gl√∂ckner lost his home during [[Bombing of Dresden in World War II]] and moved to [[Loschwitz]]. Because of his [[Formalism (art)|formalist style]], the officials of the [[East Germany|GDR]] refused him the appreciation he deserved for a long time. His rehabilitation began with an exhibition of his graphical work in the ''[[Kupferstich-Kabinett (Dresden)|Kupferstichkabinett]]'', Dresden in 1969. In 1979 he received a permanent visa for the [[West Germany|Federal Republic of Germany]]. Finally, in 1984, he was awarded with the [[National Prize of the GDR]] and the [[DEFA]] dedicated a film to him. Centrally in the area of the [[Technische Universit√§t Dresden]] he was allowed to erect a sculpture, which had been banned just a few years before. Another sculpture was erected one year later in the park of the Hotel Bellevue, Dresden's first address that time.
In his later years Gl√∂ckner regularly visited [[West Berlin]], where his cohabitee lived and where he died in 1987.<ref>[http://www.ifa.de/en/visual-arts/exhibitions-abroad/on-special-conditions/hermann-gloeckner.html Exhibition at the ''Institut f√ºr Auslandsbeziehungen'' (ifa)]</ref> Gl√∂ckner's urn was entombed in Loschwitz. A street in Loschwitz, newly built in 2008, is named after him.<ref>[http://dresden.stadtwiki.de/wiki/Hermann_Gl%C3%B6ckner Hermann Gl√∂ckner in Dresden]</ref>
==Works==
Gl√∂ckner made his works from objects he had on hand: twine, cardboard, match boxes, and wood scrapes. These common objects were put together in a unique way to create something entirely new. This art was private with the only audience being his wife.<ref>http://www.austere.co/a-history-of-hermann-glockner</ref>
